recipient_justification: Please be advised TANF25 drew funding for invoices received and processed by the California Department of Social Services for the Temporary Assistance for Needy Families Program. The draw encompasses multiple disbursements of payment. This source of funding is used to assist needy families with children so that children can be cared for in their own homes or in the homes of relatives; end the dependence of needy parents on government benefits by promoting job preparation, work, and marriage; prevent and reduce the incidence of out-of-wedlock pregnancies; and encourage the formation and maintenance of two-parent families. Particular transactions will report under #6a.
agency_lead_justification: The expenses described are consistent with those that are reasonable for accomplishing the statutory purposes of TANF.

award_description: GY2024 ORR REFUGEE CASH AND MEDICAL ASSISTANCE
recipient_justification: Florida requests $67,776,536.65 in reimbursement for eligible expenditures incurred April 1–15, 2025, under the Refugee Cash & Medical Assistance Grant (Award #2401FLRCMA, FAIN #2401FLRCMA). Costs include payroll and operations for staff managing eligibility, casework, compliance, and benefits coordination to ensure timely aid for refugees. The request also covers contracts for: (1) State Data Center and Mainframe Services supporting secure IT systems essential to program delivery; (2) Health Assessments for new arrivals to identify urgent needs and connect to care; and (3) Immunizations to protect public health and meet school/work requirements. These efforts support Assistance Listing 93.566’s goal to promote refugee integration and self-sufficiency in the U.S.
agency_lead_justification: The expenses described are consistent with the purpose of the RCMA program. The expenses as described are generally reasonable for this program.

recipient_justification:
Temporary Assistance for Needy Families Block Grant.  This payment request is used to pay for TANF program administrative costs, childcare vouchers, and work, education and training vouchers. 

The request for payment is based upon the TSA’s Monthly Payment Schedule to allow for deposit in a State account on the median business day of the month.  It is based upon a prorated share of the lesser of the annual grant divided by 12, or the total amount of Federal funds expected to be paid out for program purposes during the year divided by 12.  

ACF 196R Additional Child Welfare Services Line 20C. A request for $17.2M in compensation for the Illinois Department of Children and Family Services (IDCFS) that provides the collection of client eligibility information necessary to perform TANF eligibility determinations.  Per an IGA with IDCFS, DHS TANF compensates IDCFS $17,200,000 quarterly in the mid month of the quarter ending 6/30/25. 

ACF 196R Child Care Assistance and non-Assistance Line 11A. A request for $37M in reimbursement/compensation of Child Care Expenditures for families that need child care to work, participate in work activities, or for respite purposes.  Draws are based upon actual voucher expenditures for the month of May and anticipated needs for the remaining month of May based upon the TSA agreement.    


ACF 196R Additional Work Activities Line 9C. A request for $874,912 in reimbursement/compensation for Work Education and Training Activities contractual expenditures based upon actual voucher expenditures for the month of May and anticipated needs for the rest of the month of May based upon the TSA agreement.
agency_lead_justification: The expenses described are consistent with those that are reasonable for accomplishing the statutory purposes of TANF.

recipient_justification: This federally funded program helps thousands of foster families across Illinois provide a temporary haven for children who have been placed in the Illinois Department of Children and Family Services (DCFS) care by local courts.  The state strives to reunite these children with their birth families and nearly half of all foster children are reunited with their families within 12 months.   When reunification is not possible, as determined by the courts, many foster families choose to adopt the children they have cared for.  These funds are used for personnel costs, travel, kid’s clothing, foster care subsidy payments, and other related costs to support the foster care parents and children in DCFS care.

PWD25 - Transfer from TANF to Child Care Development Fund (CCDF) - reimbursement for child care school readiness activities

PTA25 
We are requesting payment of $15,857,587.35 for the period of 4/14/25 – 4/18/25 for the following activities.
Line 9a –Subsidized Employment -$43,057.83 – reimbursement for payment to employers or third parties to help cover the costs of employee wages, benefits, supervision, or training.
Line 9b-Education and Training - $6,288,372.47- reimbursement for education and training activities.
Line 9c-Additional Work Activities - $197,426.76 – reimbursement for job search assistance and job readiness activities.
Line 10-Work Supports - $2,766.32 – reimbursement for assistance to individuals to help obtain or maintain employment.
Line 11a-Chid Care - $4,180,653.54 – reimbursement of child care expenditures for families that need child care to work or participate in work activities and for school readiness financial assistance to eligible low-income families for early education and care.
Line 15-Non-Recurrent Short Term Benefits - $3,615.55 – reimbursement for assisting families with emergency assistance needs.
Line 18-Prevention of Out of Wedlock Pregnancies - $1,384,369.60 – reimbursement for providing services to teens and pre-teens on sex education or abstinence education and family planning services in an effort to reduce out of wedlock pregnancies.
Line 20c- Child Welfare Services-Additional Child Welfare Services -$3,700,000.00  – reimbursement for salaries and related expenses for staff overseeing program coordination, compliance, and implementation for children at risk of being removed from their homes, children’s legal services, and developing case plans.
Line 22a – Program Management - Administrative Cost – $57,325.28 reimbursement for staff salaries, benefits, staff travel, and collocated costs for staff overseeing program coordination, compliance, and implementation for children at risk of being removed from their homes.
We certify that all costs are allowable, allocable, reasonable, and necessary in accordance with the terms and conditions of the Notice of Award.

recipient_justification:
This payment request was for the Florida Child Support Program’s quarterly estimated incentives earned pursuant to the Child Support Performance and Incentive Act of 1998 (42 USC 658a.)  
As incentives are earned based on performance, the amount was determined by multiplying the annual estimate by 25%.  The annual estimate was determined by applying all states’ FFY 2023 performance (unaudited) with Florida’s cost effectiveness measure adjusted downward to the FFY 2025 incentive payment pool.  Pursuant to paragraph (d) of 42 USC 658a “The Secretary shall make the payments for the fiscal year, on a quarterly basis (with each quarterly payment being made no later than the beginning of the quarter involved), in the amounts so estimated …”
The funds will be expended on upgrading the state’s federally mandated Child Support Enforcement System consistent with the approved FY 2025 AAPDU as well as other contractual services to carry out the Title IV-D state plan.
If you have questions or require additional information please contact Christopher Ellis at chris.ellis@floridarevenue.com.
agency_lead_justification: The expenses described appear to be reasonable and consistent with the purpose of the Child Support Program.

award_description: HEAD START AND EARLY HEAD START
recipient_justification:
Subrecipient Reimbursements:
A portion of the requested funds will be allocated to reimburse our subrecipient partners for program-related expenditures they have incurred. These include allowable costs associated with service delivery, outreach, and operational support in alignment with federal Head Start guidelines. Total request is $1,409,273
Payroll Expenses:
The largest portion of our budget is dedicated to payroll for over 600 staff members who are essential to the operation of the Head Start Program. This includes educators, support staff, administrative personnel, and program coordinators. These individuals provide direct services to children and families and ensure the daily operations of the program run smoothly.  Total request is $2,066,477
Non-Personnel Operating Expenses:
In addition to staffing costs, we are requesting funds to cover necessary non-personnel expenses critical to program operations. These include monthly facility rental costs for classroom and administrative space, classroom and instructional supplies, utilities, and other operational expenses required to maintain a safe and effective learning environment.  Total request is $696,662

Grand Total -  $4,172,412
agency_lead_justification: The expenses appear to be reasonable and generally allowable for the provision of Head Start services to promote the school readiness of children from low-income families, birth to five, by fostering their cognitive, social, and emotional development through comprehensive services in early learning, health, and family well-being.

award_description: HEAD START AND EARLY HEAD START
recipient_justification:
This is the primary grant supporting the Head Start and Early Head Start programs in fulfilling their core responsibilities. These programs are designed to promote school readiness and overall well-being for low-income children and their families, with a strong emphasis on education, health, and family engagement.
Funds will be used to reimburse expenses incurred from April 30, 2025, to May 7, 2025, for the Head Start Basic, Head Start Basic Training and Technical Assistance (T and TA), Early Head Start, and Early Head Start T and TA programs administered by the Los Angeles County Office of Education (LACOE). Reimbursement will cover the following cost categories: -Certificated Personnel Salaries -Classified Personnel Salaries -Employee Benefits -Books and Supplies -Subgrantee Contracts -Services and Other Operating Expenditures -Direct Cost Transfers -Professional/Consulting Services -Capital Outlay -Indirect Costs All grantee and sub-recipient costs align with LACOE Program Year 1 (2024-25) goals and objectives.
agency_lead_justification: The expenses appear to be reasonable and generally allowable for the provision of Head Start services to promote the school readiness of children from low-income families, birth to five, by fostering their cognitive, social, and emotional development through comprehensive services in early learning, health, and family well-being.

The Missouri Child Support Program (CSP) is state administered and operates through a combination of state/county efforts to enforce judicial and administrative child support orders. recipient_justification:
This message provides a comprehensive justification for the payment request associated with Grant #90ZU058202, which funds the Home Study and Post Release Services (HS/PRS) program for Unaccompanied Alien Children, supported by the Office of Refugee Resettlement (ORR).

The total reimbursement amount requested is $3,301,330.72, covering expenses incurred during the period of March 1–31, 2025.

Program Overview:
Grant #90ZU058202 supports the delivery of Home Study and Post Release Services (HS/PRS) to Unaccompanied Alien Children (UAC) nationwide. The purpose of this program is to ensure that children released from ORR custody to sponsors are placed in safe, stable, and supportive environments, and that they receive continued monitoring and support during their adjustment and immigration proceedings.
	•	Home Studies are in-depth assessments conducted prior to a child’s release to evaluate the sponsor’s ability to provide a safe and suitable environment. These include comprehensive interviews, home inspections, and background checks in accordance with federal policy.
	•	Post Release Services are provided after reunification to ensure continued safety and well-being, including linkage to community services, school enrollment, and legal support.

A critical component of this program is the identification and mitigation of risks related to trafficking, abuse, neglect, or exploitation. Staff are trained to assess for red flags during both home studies and post-release visits. In cases where safety concerns or trafficking indicators are identified, NYAP adheres to mandated reporting requirements and actively partners with local, state, and federal law enforcement agencies to ensure appropriate intervention, investigation, and protection of the child.

NYAP provides HS/PRS across all 50 states and U.S. territories, leveraging a national network of trained professionals who respond quickly to referrals and deliver trauma-informed, culturally responsive care coordination.

Time Period Covered:
This request reflects costs incurred from March 1 to March 31, 2025.

Summary of Costs and Justification:

Salaries – $2,327,469.39
Covers case managers, supervisors, intake staff, and clinicians who provide home study evaluations, post-release visits, risk assessments, and case management across the national network.

Fringe – $345,896.06
Includes employer-paid benefits such as health insurance, payroll taxes, and retirement contributions for HS/PRS program personnel.

Supplies – $2,023.38
Includes materials necessary for assessments and case management, such as mobile technology, child safety materials, office supplies, and documentation tools.

Other – $125,307.89
Includes interpreter services, external background checks, community referrals, and other necessary program-related services not covered under other categories.

Travel – $207,597.52
Supports in-person home study and post-release visits, including transportation and lodging for staff serving rural or hard-to-reach areas to ensure nationwide coverage.

Administrative/Indirect – $293,036.48
Covers operational oversight, IT systems, reporting, compliance, and general administration required to manage and deliver the program at a national scale.

Necessity and Reasonableness:
All expenses included in this request are reasonable, necessary, and consistent with ORR’s mission and policy. These costs support NYAP’s ability to perform timely home study assessments and deliver high-quality post-release services nationwide. The program actively prevents trafficking and abuse through front-end screening and follow-up care. In compliance with federal and program policy, NYAP promptly reports safety concerns and actively collaborates with law enforcement partners as needed to ensure children’s protection.

Alignment with Federal Priorities:
All ORR-funded programs operated by the National Youth Advocate Program, including this Home Study and Post Release Services program, are implemented in accordance with federal policies and align with the President’s Executive Orders and national priorities, including:
	•	Safeguarding unaccompanied alien children before and after release
	•	Preventing exploitation, trafficking, abuse, and neglect through pre- and post-placement screening and monitoring
	•	Partnering with law enforcement for mandated reporting and child protection
	•	Ensuring court compliance and connection to legal and support services
	•	Supporting efficient immigration system processes while promoting family stabilization and long-term success

Please let us know if any additional information or documentation is required to support this request. We remain committed to protecting the safety, dignity, and well-being of every child we serve.

Total Reimbursement Request: $3,301,330.72
agency_lead_justification: The expenses described are consistent with the purpose of the National Youth Advocate Program, Inc. program. The expenses as described are generally reasonable for this program.

recipient_justification: The Oklahoma Department of Human Services (DHS) manages the Child Support Program and allocates program and administrative costs across multiple federal programs according to a cost allocation plan approved by the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (DHHS). Under Variation 1, DHS draws funds based on either the six-month average expenditure or one-third of the quarterly grant award—whichever is less. Fund draws are scheduled on the 15th of each month, promoting consistent monthly spending, minimizing draw frequency, and maintaining compliance with the Cash Management Improvement Act.
agency_lead_justification: The expenses described appear to be reasonable and consistent with the purpose of the Child Support Program.

recipient_justification:
The Child Care Subsidy program provides financial assistance low-income families to access child care so they can work or attend a job training or educational program. In addition, the program also supports investments in quality child care programs and providers, including high skills and qualifications for child care workforce, high quality standards, and other opportunities that increase quality across the early childhood spectrum. 
This request is to reimburse the costs of child care subsidy payments for low income families who are eligible for child care subsidy to assist in covering the costs of child care for the children in their family. In addition, these funds will pay for the costs of the contracts and agreements that the Child Care Subsidy program currently has to increase quality measures within the early childhood spectrum in Nebraska. Finally, the costs will support the administration of the Child Care Subsidy program including licensing staff, resource development staff and program staff who are ensuring that the Child Care subsidy program is operating appropriately and as required to meet federal requirements of the program.
agency_lead_justification: Expenditures appear consistent with grant purposes as described by the grantee.

recipient_justification:
This message provides a comprehensive justification for the payment request associated with Grant #90ZU045003, which funds the Transitional Foster Care program for Unaccompanied Alien Children, supported by the Office of Refugee Resettlement (ORR).

The total reimbursement amount requested is $2,574,761.56, covering expenses incurred during the period of March 1–31, 2025.

Program Overview:
Grant #90ZU045003 supports a Transitional Foster Care program, a short-term, temporary foster care model designed to provide safe, family-based placements for Unaccompanied Alien Children (UAC). These children are placed in licensed foster homes while approved sponsors are located and vetted. The goal is to provide temporary, trauma-informed care in a nurturing environment while facilitating timely reunification with family members or other approved sponsors.

This program operates across Arizona, Georgia, Illinois, Indiana, Louisiana, Ohio, Nevada, and South Carolina, with a combined licensed bed capacity of 480. While in care, children receive medical, mental health, educational, and case management services in alignment with ORR standards. Case managers also ensure children are informed of and attend their scheduled immigration court hearings (Notice to Appear), as required under federal immigration procedures.

The structure and delivery of these services not only support ORR’s care and custody goals but also serve as a frontline defense against trafficking and exploitation. By maintaining consistent oversight, family-based placements, and structured reunification planning, this program plays a critical role in reducing the risk of trafficking among unaccompanied alien children—a population particularly vulnerable during transitional periods.

Time Period Covered:
This request reflects costs incurred from March 1 to March 31, 2025.

Summary of Costs and Justification:

Salaries – $1,874,770.15
Supports direct care staff including clinicians, case managers, youth care workers, and program supervisors responsible for the daily care, supervision, and reunification planning of children in temporary foster placements.

Fringe – $251,050.83
Covers employer-paid benefits such as payroll taxes, health insurance, and retirement contributions for staff directly engaged in program delivery.

Supplies – $30,014.18
Includes hygiene kits, school supplies, clothing, bedding, and other essential personal care items to meet the immediate needs of children in temporary care.

Other – $235,741.21
Includes foster parent per diems, which are daily payments made to licensed foster families who provide short-term care for unaccompanied alien children. This line also includes interpretation services and other essential non-categorized program-related expenses.

Travel – $7,445.34
Covers transportation costs associated with safe and timely unification of children with their approved sponsors, a key function of the transitional foster care model.

Administrative/Indirect – $175,739.85
Supports infrastructure, compliance monitoring, IT systems, and other indirect costs necessary to operate a federally funded program across multiple sites.

Necessity and Reasonableness:
All expenses included in this payment request are reasonable, necessary, and appropriate for the continued operation of this federally funded transitional foster care program. The costs support essential program functions, including temporary placements, sponsor reunification, and case management services that ensure children remain in safe, supervised environments.

This program not only fulfills immediate care obligations but also actively reduces the risk of trafficking and exploitation by preventing the release of children into unsafe conditions and ensuring court compliance and coordinated service delivery.

Alignment with Federal Priorities:
All ORR-funded programs operated by the National Youth Advocate Program, including this Transitional Foster Care program, are implemented in accordance with federal guidelines and align with the President’s Executive Orders and national priorities, including:
	•	Providing care and protection for vulnerable unaccompanied alien children
	•	Facilitating safe and appropriate family reunification
	•	Preventing exploitation and trafficking of children
	•	Supporting efficient immigration system processes through oversight, coordination, and service delivery

Please let us know if any additional information or documentation is required to support this request. We remain committed to accountability, compliance, and excellence in our service to unaccompanied alien children.

Total Reimbursement Request: $2,574,761.56
agency_lead_justification: The expenses described are consistent with the purpose of the National Youth Advocate Program, Inc. program. The expenses as described are generally reasonable for this program.

recipient_justification: The City of Chicago Department of Family and Support Services’ (DFSS) Children Services Division (CSD) coordinates the largest high quality early learning services network in the city of Chicago. Early learning services are provided through community-based sub-recipient agencies and their partners.  The draw down request consists of funds necessary to sustain these programs operating in 35 high need neighborhoods.  The expenses include personnel costs, operating costs, professional services and training costs.  All costs requested for draw down align with the details submitted in our grant application and subsequently awarded in our received Notice of Awards.
agency_lead_justification: The expenses appear to be reasonable and generally allowable for the provision of Head Start services to promote the school readiness of children from low-income families, birth to five, by fostering their cognitive, social, and emotional development through comprehensive services in early learning, health, and family well-being.

recipient_justification: HIAS' Preferred Communities Program started on 9/30/24 and ends on 9/29/25. This program serves eligible vulnerable clients to reach self-sufficiency and to integrate into their communities through intensive case management, group-based programming and GAP services. PC services include extended cultural and community orientation on navigating systems in the US and linkages to community resources and supportive social services as appropriate. PC builds affiliate capacity through outreach, partnerships, and volunteers. HIAS ensures that service providers have the required training, oversight, and support to succeed in their roles. This payment request pertains to expenditures incurred during the months of March and April 2025. These expenses fall within the approved budget categories of the grant, including a) salaries and fringe benefits for personnel directly involved in program case management services; b) affiliate partner(s)-related expenditures; and c) indirect cost recovery.
agency_lead_justification: The expenses described are consistent with the purpose of the program. The expenses as described are generally reasonable for this program.

recipient_justification:
The request being made is for funding of payroll (BUDGET LINE PERSONNEL) and related tax and benefits payments (BUDGET LINE FRINGE) for 629 people to assist in placing unaccompanied alien children in safe homes with rigorously vetted and documented family members or sponsors. These staff members are located throughout the United States in order to best support the needs and mission of the Administration for Children and Families. These funds are to pay payroll and related fringe for the period of 4-28-2025 to 5-11-2025.

Staff are compensated in accordance with the U.S. Department of Labor McNamara-O'Hara Service Contract Act (SCA). Because these staff members work and reside in different states with different compensation requirements and thresholds, each is paid the prevailing wage determination based on where they are performing their duties. These staff members consist of the following positions as approved and appropriated by the grant:

Direct Care staff, Case Managers, Case Aides, Intake staff, Administrative Assistants, Personnel Resources support staff, Regional support staff, Training staff, Site directors and supervisors, compliance and analytical staff, and logistics staff.

Total requested is as follows:
Personnel: Salaries and Wages - $1,638,327.93
Fringe: Payroll Taxes - $123,934.31
Fringe: State Unemployment - $3,595.31
Fringe: Worker’s Compensation Insurance - $18,789.81
Fringe: Retirement Expense - $56,115.45
Indirect Expense (15%) - $276,114.42

President Trump and Secretary Kennedy have affirmatively stated that the federal government will not be complicit in the tacit trafficking of unaccompanied alien children –who are extraordinarily vulnerable to exploitation – by failing to require proven connections between adult sponsors and children and failing to conduct thorough safety assessments prior to and following placement into a home. The positions stated above are necessary to fulfill this mission and have been appropriated under the terms of the grant. This work includes intake, home visitation, interviewing, reunification recommendation, services planning, and significant incident reporting on an individual basis for each child. 

Without these professionals it would not be possible for our organization to meet the requirements of our cooperative agreement with the US Department of Health and Human Services, which could imperil the agency’s capacity and ability to respond to critical matters of national and border security.
agency_lead_justification: The expenses described are consistent with the purpose of the COMPASS CONNECTIONS program. The expenses as described are generally reasonable for this program.

recipient_justification:
Per your request for additional information, the grant #90ZU0529-03 Residential (Shelter and/or Transitional Foster Care Services for Unaccompanied Children requires fully staffed facilities to house 425 beds to be used to care for unaccompanied children. Two of these shelters are in the El Paso, TX region, and the third shelter is located in Nueces County, TX. The grant specifies in the narrative the allocation of $46,363,026 for Personnel costs, along with $13,937,312 in Fringe related costs for the staffing of these shelter facilities. These expenses are direct costs to this contract, and without the people that are hired to manage and care for the children, it would be impossible to meet the provisions of the agreement. 

As the Department of Labor determined that the personnel that are hired under this grant are subject to Service Contract Act provisions, there is an obligation to pay wages and fringe as based on the Wage Determination No 2015-5229 for the El Paso locations and Wage Determination No 2015-5225 for the Nueces Co Location. As such, Compass Connections is mandated to pay wages and fringe benefits as prescribed by the Federal directives outlined in each of those determinations. 

These funds requested are for payroll period start date of 4/14/25 through end date of 4/27/25 already expended. 607 staff were paid during this pay period. Totals are: Salaries and Wages $1,671,554.27; Retirement Expense $55,565.27; Payroll Taxes $126,644.79; Payroll Tax SUI $440.28; Workers Compensation $11,363.67; Indirect Cost $279,835.25 for total expenditures incurred in the amount of $2,145,403.53.
agency_lead_justification: The expenses described are consistent with the purpose of the COMPASS CONNECTIONS program. The expenses as described are generally reasonable for this program.

recipient_justification: The March 2025 Preferred Communities(PC) payment request seeks to cover program-related expenses, including personnel, fringe benefits, travel, professional fees, office and client support costs, and indirect expenses. The Preferred Communities (PC) program under the regular funding aim to support the long-term integration and self-sufficiency of vulnerable refugee and other ORR-eligible populations through intensive case management (ICM), extended services, and enhance site capacities. PC regular focuses on supporting local sites in delivering tailored services, strengthening organizational capacity, and engaging communities through outreach. It also involves cultural orientation, interpretation services, and emergency client assistance. The PC GAPS programs under supplemental funding (ASA, UHP, REA, Housing) provide a one-off service or a 90-day gap services to Afghan and Ukrainian parolees, unaccompanied minors, medically fragile individuals, and those facing housing instability.
agency_lead_justification: The expenses described are consistent with the purpose of the program. The expenses as described are generally reasonable for this program.

recipient_justification: Reason for Payment Request Justification: Payment Justification -The Federal Temporary Assistance for Needy Families block grant is received from the Federal Department of Health and Human Services, Administration for Children and Families. This grant provides assistance to needy families with children (or expecting) to ensure children can be cared for in their own homes or in the homes of relatives; end the dependence of low-income parents on government benefits by promoting job preparation, work and marriage; prevent and reduce the incidence of out-of-wedlock pregnancies and establish numerical goals for preventing and reducing the incidence of these pregnancies; and encourage the formation and maintenance of two-parent families. The TANF block grant allows states to carry over remaining grant authority each year until the funds are fully drawn. TANF funds categories 01, 02, 03, 04, 12, 26, 30, 87 88, and 89 based on the Division's federally approved Public Assistance Cost Allocation
agency_lead_justification:
The expenses described are consistent with those that are reasonable for accomplishing the statutory purposes of TANF.

recipient_justification: Florida requests $1,800,000.00 in reimbursement under the Social Services Block Grant (SSBG), Award #2501FLTANF-01, FAIN #2501FLTANF, for eligible expenditures incurred from April 1–16, 2025. The costs include salary, wages, and fringe benefits for staff overseeing program coordination, compliance, and service implementation, as well as associated indirect costs. It also covers payments to qualified providers delivering SSBG-supported services such as child protective services, case management, employment assistance, and family support. These expenditures are essential to advancing the SSBG’s objectives—reducing dependency, promoting self-sufficiency, preventing institutionalization, and supporting vulnerable populations. All expenditures comply with federal requirements and support the continued delivery of vital services to Florida’s eligible families.

recipient_justification: The requested draw for Grant# 90ZU0528-02 Residential (Shelter and/or Transitional Foster Care) Services for Unaccompanied Children requesting reimbursement for funds expended during the Period of 04-01-24 to 03-31-25 not reimbursed in prior payments. These expenditures represent the costs necessary to staff facilities and provide food, clothing, medical and housing for the clients currently sheltering in three facilities, two in San Antonio, TX, and one in Baytown, Texas, with a 358 bed capacity. Through 03-31-25, $71,238,696.45 in approved expenditures have been paid for the support and care of the clients, and $69,513,710.74 has been reimbursed for these services. As such, Compass Connections is requesting a payment of $1,724,985.71. Through 03-31-25 Direct costs consist of the following: Personnel- $41,659,125.46; Fringe- $6,769,878.72; Supplies- $1,662,437.31; Travel- $50,378.91; Contractual- $438,724.18; and Other- $14,323,427.15. Indirect costs total $6,334,724.71.

recipient_justification: The requested draw for Grant# 90ZU0525-02 Residential (Shelter and/or Transitional Foster Care) Services for Unaccompanied Children requesting reimbursement for funds expended during the Period of 04-01-24 to 03-31-25 not reimbursed in prior payments. These expenditures represent the costs necessary to staff facilities and provide food, clothing, medical and housing for the clients currently sheltering in two facilities in South Texas with a 525 bed capacity. Through 03-31-25, $86,892,659.9 in approved expenditures have been paid for the support and care of the clients, and $85,402,567.17 has been reimbursed for these services. As such, Compass Connections is requesting a payment of $1,490,092.73. Through 03-31-25 Direct costs consist of the following: Personnel- $47,256,731.99; Fringe- $13,891,094.81; Supplies- $2,439,605.25; Travel- $45,743.98; Contractual- $233,288.41; and Other- $15,563,929.93. Indirect costs total $7,462,265.52.
agency_lead_justification: The expenses described are consistent with the purpose of the COMPASS CONNECTIONS program. The expenses as described are generally reasonable for this program.

recipient_justification: This request supports payment for IT services essential to enhancing the effectiveness and efficiency of professional caseworker staff. These services include the development, implementation, and maintenance of secure digital platforms that streamline case documentation, enable real-time data access, and improve service coordination. By leveraging modern technology, caseworkers can more effectively assess family needs, monitor progress, and ensure timely interventions. These tools reduce administrative burden, enhance decision-making, and directly contribute to improved outcomes for children and families. The IT services align with federal and state mandates, including FFPSA goals, and are critical to sustaining high-quality, prevention-oriented child welfare services.
agency_lead_justification: The expenses described appear consistent with the purpose of the formula program.

award_description: HEAD START AND EARLY HEAD START
recipient_justification:
All expenses relate to the Head Start and Early Head Start programs serving children ages 2-5.
Personnel $751,828.20 - April salary for teachers, teacher assistants, center supervisors, home educators, records clerks, custodians, health staff, disabilities staff, and additional support staff to provide comprehensive services to enrolled children 
Fringe $499,226.68 - April fringe benefits that correspond to  salaries above
Travel $461.13 - Mileage and Per Diem reimbursement for travel to the Early Childhood STEM conference on April 1-2ndSupplies $8,713.64 - Instructional materials for preschool and toddler classrooms and maintenance supplies
Other $97,878.14 - Expenses include $25,823.81 utilities, $1,504.48 copier lease, $9,860.76 minor repairs to sites to ensure all buildings are safe, $55,523.92 leases of facilities, $102.65 teacher permit renewal, $5,062.52 for socializations for enrolled children in the home Base option.  Socializations allow the opportunity for enrolled children that are not in a traditional center base setting to learn and socialize with other children. 
Contractual $7,742.90 -  Contract to provide mental health screening, case management and referrals to enrolled children 
Indirect $102,129.71 - indirect administrative expense at the approved rate of 7.52%
agency_lead_justification: The expenses appear to be reasonable and generally allowable for the provision of Head Start services to promote the school readiness of children from low-income families, birth to five, by fostering their cognitive, social, and emotional development through comprehensive services in early learning, health, and family well-being.

recipient_justification:
The activities related to this drawdown, 1,420,199.84, include Matching Grant case management, employment services and direct support (e.g., housing, utilities, food) for ORR eligible populations that promote participant economic self-sufficiency during the service period. The expenses are aligned with the approved award objectives and budget and are needed to ensure the award requirements are met by serving ORR eligible populations to achieve the self-sufficiency outcomes. The timeframe is March 1, 2025 – March 31, 2025, where most of the expenses are contractual and relate to case management, job development, housing, and other direct support carried out by CWS local offices and affiliates for the clients enrolled.
The following is a recap of the expense by budget-line items
·       Personnel 
·       Fringe Benefits 
·       Travel 
·       Supplies 
·       Contractual 
·       Other Direct Program 
·       Indirect

recipient_justification: This is a payment request from the Child Support Incentive grant.  States earn incentive funds from the federal government based on their performance on five performance measures.  These funds are required to be reinvested into the Child Support program.  The Child Support program is a joint federal, state, and local effort to secure financial support from noncustodial parents.  These incentives are designed to incentivize states to collect more child support, establish more paternity and support orders, and improve their overall performance.

recipient_justification: These payments were made in accordance with our approved IV-E state plan. These payments were made to support and enhance timely permanency services for children in Pennsylvania who are in the custody of county children and youth agencies and to provide post-permanency support services to families.  Services provided include direct services such as child profile, child preparation, child specific recruitment, family profile, placement, finalization and post-permanency services.  Support services are also provided including the Pennsylvania Adoption Exchange, the Legal Services Initiative, the SWAN Helpline, training, technical assistance, conferencing, matching services and activities, the American Bar Association’s Barriers to Permanency Project, support for the Pennsylvania State Resource Family Association and public relations support.

recipient_justification:
Please see justification below.

1. Salaries and Benefits:
The allocation for salaries and benefits is critical to ensure that we can retain qualified educators and staff who provide high-quality instruction and support to our children and families. This funding will cover the salaries of teachers, support staff, and management staff, along with necessary benefits such as health insurance and retirement contributions. By investing in our personnel, we enhance student learning outcomes and program morale.
2. Substitute Teachers:
Funding for substitute teachers is essential to maintain instructional continuity when regular teachers are absent due to illness, professional development, or personal matters. This line item ensures that students receive uninterrupted instruction, allowing for consistent learning experiences. It also supports the wellbeing of our teachers by enabling them to take necessary leave without compromising student education.
3. Classroom Supplies:
Classroom supplies are vital for creating an engaging and effective learning environment. This budget line will cover essential materials such as crayons, easel paper, primary pencils, newsprint paper, and other educational resources that facilitate hands-on learning and support diverse instructional strategies. Investing in classroom supplies directly impacts student engagement and academic success.
4. Health Supplies:
The allocation for health supplies is crucial for maintaining a safe and healthy school environment. This includes items such as first aid kits supplies, gloves, pull-ups, cleaning supplies, and other health resource materials that help mitigate the spread of illness among students and staff. By prioritizing health supplies, we demonstrate our commitment to the well-being of our school community, which is especially important in light of recent health concerns.
5. Vision Screener:
Investing in a vision screener is necessary to ensure that all students receive early detection and intervention for vision issues that may hinder their academic performance. By providing this essential health screening, we can identify students who may need further evaluation and support, ultimately contributing to their overall success and well-being.
6. Technology Supplies for Printer Ink:
Funding for printer ink is essential to support the administrative needs of both classrooms and offices. This allows for the printing of instructional materials, student assessments, and important communications to parents and the community. Having reliable access to printed materials enhances our ability to deliver effective instruction and maintain efficient operations.
In summary, each line item in this budget is designed to support the educational mission of our program, ensuring that we have the necessary resources to provide a high-quality learning environment for all students. Thank you for considering this justification for our budget request.

recipient_justification:
This message provides a comprehensive justification for the payment request associated with Grant #90ZU050802, which funds the Transitional Foster Care program for Unaccompanied Alien Children, supported by the Office of Refugee Resettlement (ORR).

The total reimbursement amount requested is $1,257,355.11, covering expenses incurred during the period of March 1–31, 2025.

Program Overview:
Grant #90ZU050802 supports a Transitional Foster Care program, a short-term, temporary foster care model designed to provide safe, family-based placements for Unaccompanied Alien Children (UAC). These children are placed in licensed foster homes while approved sponsors are located and vetted. The goal is to provide temporary, trauma-informed care in a nurturing environment while facilitating timely reunification with family members or other approved sponsors.

This program operates across Arizona, Georgia, Illinois, Ohio, and South Carolina, with a combined licensed bed capacity of 252. While in care, children receive medical, mental health, educational, and case management services in alignment with ORR standards. Case managers also ensure children are informed of and attend their scheduled immigration court hearings (Notice to Appear), as required under federal immigration procedures.

The structure and delivery of these services not only support ORR’s care and custody goals but also serve as a frontline defense against trafficking and exploitation. By maintaining consistent oversight, family-based placements, and structured reunification planning, this program plays a critical role in reducing the risk of trafficking among unaccompanied alien children—a population particularly vulnerable during transitional periods.

Time Period Covered:
This request reflects costs incurred from March 1 to March 31, 2025.

Summary of Costs and Justification:

Salaries – $886,524.57
Supports direct care staff including clinicians, case managers, youth care workers, and program supervisors responsible for the daily care, supervision, and reunification planning of children in temporary foster placements.

Fringe – $127,260.76
Covers employer-paid benefits such as payroll taxes, health insurance, and retirement contributions for staff directly engaged in program delivery.

Supplies – $10,098.38
Includes hygiene kits, school supplies, clothing, bedding, and other essential personal care items to meet the immediate needs of children in temporary care.

Other – $139,199.80
Includes foster parent per diems, which are daily payments made to licensed foster families who provide short-term care for unaccompanied alien children. This line also includes interpretation services and other essential non-categorized program-related expenses.

Travel – $1,552.75
Covers transportation costs associated with safe and timely unification of children with their approved sponsors, a key function of the transitional foster care model.

Administrative/Indirect – $92,718.85
Supports infrastructure, compliance monitoring, IT systems, and other indirect costs necessary to operate a federally funded program across multiple sites.

Necessity and Reasonableness:
All expenses included in this payment request are reasonable, necessary, and appropriate for the continued operation of this federally funded transitional foster care program. The costs support essential program functions, including temporary placements, sponsor reunification, and case management services that ensure children remain in safe, supervised environments.

This program not only fulfills immediate care obligations but also actively reduces the risk of trafficking and exploitation by preventing the release of children into unsafe conditions and ensuring court compliance and coordinated service delivery.

Alignment with Federal Priorities:
All ORR-funded programs operated by the National Youth Advocate Program, including this Transitional Foster Care program, are implemented in accordance with federal guidelines and align with the President’s Executive Orders and national priorities, including:
	•	Providing care and protection for vulnerable unaccompanied alien children
	•	Facilitating safe and appropriate family reunification
	•	Preventing exploitation and trafficking of children
	•	Supporting efficient immigration system processes through oversight, coordination, and service delivery

Please let us know if any additional information or documentation is required to support this request. We remain committed to accountability, compliance, and excellence in our service to unaccompanied alien children.

Total Reimbursement Request: $1,257,355.11
agency_lead_justification: The expenses described are consistent with the purpose of the National Youth Advocate Program, Inc. program. The expenses as described are generally reasonable for this program.

recipient_justification: The requested payment is to cover expenses incurred for the Toledo Public Schools Head Start Program during the period of December 1, 2024, through March 31, 2025. These expenses include salaries and fringe benefits for instructional and support staff who directly contribute to early childhood education, classroom supplies essential for delivering developmentally appropriate curriculum, and travel costs for staff training and family engagement activities. Contractual services are necessary for health screenings and specialized education services, ensuring compliance with Head Start Performance Standards. award_description: HEAD START AND EARLY HEAD START
recipient_justification:
The expenses included in this payment request for operating the CCA's Head Start and Early Head Start program are as follows:

Personnel Costs: Salaries and benefits for teachers, aides, and staff who are directly involved in implementing the program’s services.

Building Costs: Payments for utilities, pest control, and cleaning services necessary to maintain the buildings where Head Start and Early Head Start children are served.

Local Travel: Reimbursed mileage for staff working directly with children, as well as Head Start and Early Head Start staff traveling between centers to provide coaching, family services, and other program-related activities. Rate of reimbursement is based on IRS regulations.

Indirect Costs: Expenses calculated using an approved Federally negotiated indirect cost rate based on Personnel Costs, charged to the grant for costs allowable under federal guidelines.

This request reflects costs that are compliant with grant requirements and are essential to the operation of the Head Start and Early Head Start program. Let me know if further clarification is needed.

award_description: HEAD START AND EARLY HEAD START
recipient_justification:
Salaries: $728,458.53. This is used to cover teachers, paras, family support workers, office staff, & Headstart director pay for paycheck dates from 3/14/2025 – 4/25/2025. Teachers and Paras align with the educational component of the Headstart Program. While family support workers help support the family involvement component of the Headstart Program. The office staff and director help support the program by doing the necessary reports, completing applications, and any other duties to make sure the program is running.

Fringe: $271,705.98. Fringe benefits support the staff and dates mentioned above.

Mileage: $994.24. Family support workers travel to schools and homes of the students in the Headstart program the date reimbursed would be between 3/14/2025 – 4/25/2025 since they are reimbursed on their paycheck.

Classroom supplies: $29.73.  Envelopes for mailing families which align with family involvement component as well. This expense was charged in April.

T&TA: $4,798.94. Includes Invoices for the Children’s Museum ($3,097), author visits ($600), That Pottery Place ($239), Its Yours Pottery ($330) & Wildlife Encounters ($325) that were for family engagement, which also has a training component for parents. There is also another invoice from Valentinos ($207.94) for food for the Health Services Advisory Committee that was being trained on mental health services. This helps support the health component of the Headstart program.   

Indirect Cost: $80,478.99. We have an indirect cost rate of 8% that was accepted in our application. This helps us recover costs for our HR, financial, and admin staff that are not directly charged to the grant but helps the Headstart program run.

award_description: HEAD START AND EARLY HEAD START
recipient_justification: As part of our Head Start and Early Head Start grant award by the Department of Health and Human Services Administration for Children and Families, for Fiscal Year 2024-2025, pre-approved and granted to Umatilla-Morrow Head Start, Inc. in July 2024, we are proceeding with the purchase of a modular unit to redevelop one of our key program locations in Hermiston, Oregon. This funding is critical in addressing the urgent need to replace an outdated and deteriorating facility that no longer meets safety, accessibility, or programmatic standards in serving our children and their families. This new facility will ensure that 24 infants/toddlers and their families continue to receive safe, high-quality care. With funding secured and planning completed, we are ready to move into construction. The modular solution will allow us to provide a modern, safe, and efficient space for our services, ensuring continuity and improvement of program delivery for the community we serve.

recipient_justification:
Updated Justification for Subaccount 05CH01248801 (Closeout and Final Drawdown)

This request represents the final drawdown for PMS Account A353P Subaccount 05CH01248801 and serves as the closeout for the Head Start program grant for the fiscal year ending January 31, 2025. The expenses covered in this final request are essential to completing the program’s activities and are necessary to ensure the smooth continuation and closure of operations for the grant period.

The requested funds will cover the following:

Contracted Partner Payments: Payments to Head Start partners, including child care providers and educational service contractors, for services provided during the grant period. These payments are necessary to ensure the continuity and quality of services for the children and families enrolled in the program.

Facility Costs: Payments for rent, utilities, and maintenance services for the Head Start centers. These costs are required to maintain a safe and conducive learning environment for the children enrolled in the program.

Employee Benefits and Salaries: These expenses are related to the compensation of program staff, including teachers, assistants, and administrative personnel. Employee benefits, such as health insurance and retirement contributions, are essential to retaining a qualified workforce to deliver the Head Start program effectively.

Program Supplies and Equipment: This includes the purchase of classroom materials, educational supplies, and program-specific equipment necessary for the day-to-day operations of the Head Start centers.

Training and Development: Funding will support staff professional development, ensuring that all Head Start staff remain up-to-date with the latest educational standards and practices.

This final drawdown is consistent with the objectives of the Head Start program and necessary to fulfill the mission of providing high-quality early childhood education and family services. All costs were incurred within the approved grant period and are fully aligned with the goals outlined in the award. This drawdown will complete the financial obligations under this grant, and no further expenditures are anticipated for this subaccount.
agency_lead_justification: The expenses described are generally reasonable and consistent with the purpose of the Head Start Grant program.

recipient_justification:
This message provides a comprehensive justification for the payment request associated with Grant #90ZU049803, which funds the Transitional Foster Care program for Unaccompanied Alien Children, supported by the Office of Refugee Resettlement (ORR).

The total reimbursement amount requested is $977,283.92, covering expenses incurred during the period of March 1–31, 2025.

Program Overview:
Grant #90ZU049803 supports a Transitional Foster Care program, a short-term, temporary foster care model designed to provide safe, family-based placements for Unaccompanied Alien Children (UAC). These children are placed in licensed foster homes while approved sponsors are located and vetted. The goal is to provide temporary, trauma-informed care in a nurturing environment while facilitating timely reunification with family members or other approved sponsors.

This program operates across Colorado, Virginia, and Wisconsin, with a combined licensed bed capacity of 90. While in care, children receive medical, mental health, educational, and case management services in alignment with ORR standards. Case managers also ensure children are informed of and attend their scheduled immigration court hearings (Notice to Appear), as required under federal immigration procedures.

The structure and delivery of these services not only support ORR’s care and custody goals but also serve as a frontline defense against trafficking and exploitation. By maintaining consistent oversight, family-based placements, and structured reunification planning, this program plays a critical role in reducing the risk of trafficking among unaccompanied alien children—a population particularly vulnerable during transitional periods.

Time Period Covered:
This request reflects costs incurred from March 1 to March 31, 2025.

Summary of Costs and Justification:

Salaries – $563,635.06
Supports direct care staff including clinicians, case managers, youth care workers, and program supervisors responsible for the daily care, supervision, and reunification planning of children in temporary foster placements.

Fringe – $137,252.68
Covers employer-paid benefits such as payroll taxes, health insurance, and retirement contributions for staff directly engaged in program delivery.

Supplies – $32,491.06
Includes hygiene kits, school supplies, clothing, bedding, and other essential personal care items to meet the immediate needs of children in temporary care.

Other – $153,926.85
Includes foster parent per diems, which are daily payments made to licensed foster families who provide short-term care for unaccompanied alien children. This line also includes interpretation services and other essential non-categorized program-related expenses.

Travel – $1,234.56
Covers transportation costs associated with safe and timely unification of children with their approved sponsors, a key function of the transitional foster care model.

Administrative/Indirect – $88,743.71
Supports infrastructure, compliance monitoring, IT systems, and other indirect costs necessary to operate a federally funded program across multiple sites.

Necessity and Reasonableness:
All expenses included in this payment request are reasonable, necessary, and appropriate for the continued operation of this federally funded transitional foster care program. The costs support essential program functions, including temporary placements, sponsor reunification, and case management services that ensure children remain in safe, supervised environments.

This program not only fulfills immediate care obligations but also actively reduces the risk of trafficking and exploitation by preventing the release of children into unsafe conditions and ensuring court compliance and coordinated service delivery.

Alignment with Federal Priorities:
All ORR-funded programs operated by the National Youth Advocate Program, including this Transitional Foster Care program, are implemented in accordance with federal guidelines and align with the President’s Executive Orders and national priorities, including:
	•	Providing care and protection for vulnerable unaccompanied alien children
	•	Facilitating safe and appropriate family reunification
	•	Preventing exploitation and trafficking of children
	•	Supporting efficient immigration system processes through oversight, coordination, and service delivery

Please let us know if any additional information or documentation is required to support this request. We remain committed to accountability, compliance, and excellence in our service to unaccompanied alien children.

Total Reimbursement Request: $977,283.92
agency_lead_justification: The expenses described are consistent with the purpose of the National Youth Advocate Program, Inc. program. The expenses as described are generally reasonable for this program.

recipient_justification:
Grant #90ZU047903 supports a Transitional Foster Care program, a short-term, temporary foster care model designed to provide safe, family-based placements for Unaccompanied Alien Children (UAC). These children are placed in licensed foster homes while approved sponsors are located and vetted. The program prevents prolonged institutionalization and offers immediate stability through temporary placements, with children typically remaining in care for 30 to 90 days.

This program operates across three offices in Georgia, Illinois, and Indiana, supporting a combined bed capacity of 168. While in care, children receive trauma-informed support services including medical, mental health, education, and case management. Importantly, case managers ensure children are aware of and attend their scheduled immigration court hearings (Notice to Appear) as required under federal immigration procedures.

The Transitional Foster Care model serves as a critical safeguard, reducing vulnerability to human trafficking by maintaining consistent oversight, family-based care, and structured reunification planning.

Time Period Covered:

This request reflects costs incurred from March 1 to March 31, 2025.

Summary of Costs and Justification:
	•	Salaries – $712,726.92
Covers compensation for staff including case managers, clinicians, youth care workers, and supervisory roles who directly support children in temporary foster care.
	•	Fringe – $71,818.54
Includes employer-paid benefits such as payroll taxes, health insurance, and retirement for staff engaged in daily care and reunification work.
	•	Supplies – $11,335.83
Includes basic needs for children such as hygiene products, clothing, bedding, and school supplies.
	•	Other – $53,639.80
Includes foster parent per diems, which are daily stipends paid to licensed foster families to support the temporary care of children. Also includes interpretation services and other essential non-categorized program costs.
	•	Travel – $1,270.97
Supports transportation related to unification with approved sponsors, ensuring safe, timely family reunification in accordance with ORR guidelines.
	•	Administrative/Indirect – $92,773.75
Supports operational infrastructure, including compliance, IT, facilities, and indirect costs necessary to maintain program quality and federal accountability across multiple locations.

Necessity and Reasonableness:

All expenses are reasonable, necessary, and appropriate to the delivery of federally funded transitional foster care services. The budget supports child-centered, temporary placements and services that promote reunification while ensuring that children attend their court proceedings and are protected from harm.

The program’s structured environment and monitoring serve as a preventative barrier against human trafficking, ensuring that children are not left in vulnerable, unsupervised, or unsafe conditions during this critical transition period.

Alignment with Federal Priorities:

All ORR-funded programs operated by the National Youth Advocate Program, including this Transitional Foster Care program, are delivered in alignment with federal policies, grant requirements, and the President’s Executive Orders and national priorities. These include:
	•	Prioritizing the safety and well-being of unaccompanied alien children;
	•	Strengthening family reunification systems;
	•	Preventing exploitation and human trafficking;
	•	Supporting efficient immigration system processes through timely case coordination and oversight.

Please let us know if any additional information is required. We remain committed to accountability and excellence in our service to vulnerable children and to the effective use of federal funds.
agency_lead_justification: The expenses described are consistent with the purpose of the National Youth Advocate Program, Inc. program. The expenses as described are generally reasonable for this program.

recipient_justification: "Grant 2501MTTANF - 7.c. EmergencyAssistance Authorized Solely Under Prior Law ($30,670.08) 11.a. Child Care (Assistance and Non-Assistance) $2,722.50 For a total of ($27,947.58) Direct Services on 696 - discretionary funds childcare subsidy. Indirects DPHHS employees in the TANF Division work on multiple federal grants; therefore, their payroll, rent, and other corresponding administration is cost allocated based on statistics of how much time was spent working on each grant (please also see Montana’s PACAP).  We have a federally approved PACAP and our indirect costs are overhead costs that are in the approved PACAP based on statistic in the following allocation methodologies: FTE Based, Time and Effort based, Transaction based, Eligibility based, and federally pre-approved allocation statistics.  As Montana only processes actual cost allocation results on a quarterly basis, daily estimated indirects are posted to each federal grant, based on a daily average from the previous quarter’

The funds requested are necessary to maintain continuous operations and services that directly support the delivery of high-quality early childhood education and family services. Specifically, the requested funds will cover multiple categories of expenditures, including payroll, employee health benefits, facility operations, transportation, professional services, and programmatic support costs incurred or anticipated for the periods ending April 30, 2025, and May 1, 2025. These costs are consistent with the approved budgets for each grant and are essential for uninterrupted service delivery to enrolled children, families, and program staff. award_description: GY 2022 REFUGEE SUPPORT SERVICES AND SET ASIDES
recipient_justification: This award is for the Refugee Support Services (RSS) program, funded by the Office of Refugee Resettlement (ORR). RSS is used primarily for services designed to enable ORR-eligible populations to obtain jobs within one year of enrolling in services to achieve economic self-sufficiency as soon as possible. RSS also addresses barriers to employment, such as social adjustment, interpretation, and translation. This drawdown is for the continuation of the RSS program in April for New Jersey. These funds cover IRC’s RSS administrative expenses, including salaries, fringe, and associated operational costs such as facilities and equipment, and payments for RSS administrative expenses to IRC’s ten sub-awardees in New Jersey for their RSS implementation during this period

These expenditures represent the costs necessary to staff and establish offices to provide case management and home study services in all cities nationally, with the acceptance of 2,000 Home Study and 17,500 cases annually. Through 03-31-25, $18,760,251.85 in approved expenditures have been paid for the support and care of the clients, and $18,036,859.43 has been reimbursed for these services. As such, Compass Connections is requesting a payment of $723,392.42. Through 03-31-25 Direct costs consist of the following: Personnel- $11,383,351.43; Fringe- $2,782,193.85; Supplies- $48,879.14; Travel- $.; Contractual- $24,519.24; Equipment- $.; and Other- $2,119,275.21. Indirect costs total $2,402,032.98

award_description: HEAD START AND EARLY HEAD START
recipient_justification:
Wu Yee Children’s Services is requesting funding to cover expenses incurred from March 1, 2025, to March 31, 2025, for its Early Head Start and Head Start programs. These expenses support the ongoing operation and delivery of services across our 12 centers during the covered period.

Expenses fall under the following approved budget categories:
* Personnel: Salaries for direct program staff, including center-based teaching staff and administrative personnel, to ensure smooth daily operations and program delivery.
* Fringe Benefits: Costs associated with employee benefits such as medical, dental, vision, workers’ compensation, AD&D, and life insurance.
* Supplies: Purchase of necessary supplies for classrooms and offices, including educational materials, cleaning products, and general office supplies.
* Other: Operational costs including rent, utilities, janitorial services, telephone/internet, building repairs and maintenance, equipment leasing and maintenance, and security services. This category also includes administrative costs such as general liability insurance, payroll processing fees, and technology-related expenses.

This request reflects the actual expenses necessary to maintain high-quality early childhood education and family support services throughout the month of March 2025.
agency_lead_justification: The expenses appear to be reasonable and generally allowable for the provision of Head Start services to promote the school readiness of children from low-income families, birth to five, by fostering their cognitive, social, and emotional development through comprehensive services in early learning, health, and family well-being.

recipient_justification: Please be advised TANF25 drew funding for invoices received and processed by the California Department of Social Services for the Temporary Assistance for Needy Families Program. The draw encompasses multiple disbursements of payment. This source of funding is used to assist needy families with children so that children can be cared for in their own homes or in the homes of relatives; end the dependence of needy parents on government benefits by promoting job preparation, work, and marriage; prevent and reduce the incidence of out-of-wedlock pregnancies; and encourage the formation and maintenance of two-parent families. Particular transactions will report under #22a.
agency_lead_justification:
The expenses described are consistent with those that are reasonable for accomplishing the statutory purposes of TANF.

JUST A REMINDR TO REFERENCE ACF 196R EXPENDITURE CATEGORIES IN REQUESTS: When submitting requests for reimbursements, descriptions such as listing line item expenditure categories from the ACF-196R instructions (https://acf.gov/ofa/programs/tanf/reporting-instructions) in the justification are sufficient and will expedite processing.

recipient_justification: Please be advised FC25 drew funding for invoices received and processed by the California Department of Social Services for Foster Care. The draw encompasses multiple disbursements of payment. This source of funding provides safe and stable out-of-home care for children under the jurisdiction of the state or tribal child welfare agency until the children are returned home safely, placed with adoptive families, or placed in other planned arrangements for permanency. The program provides funds to assist with the costs of foster care maintenance for eligible children; administrative costs to manage the program; and training for public agency staff, foster parents and eligible professional partner agency staff. PMS 05/08/2025

These expenses include facility-related costs such as real estate taxes and one-time deep cleaning services, which are allowable under 45 CFR §75.452 and HSPPS §1302.47(b)(1)(ix) as part of maintaining safe, healthy, and efficient program environments. Waste removal was conducted to support facility safety and organization per §1302.47. The draw also covers janitorial services, health supplies, and paper products required for daily operations in alignment with §1302.47(b)(1)(ii)(2)(i). recipient_justification: Please be advised TANF25 drew funding for invoices received and processed by the California Department of Social Services for the Temporary Assistance for Needy Families Program. The draw encompasses multiple disbursements of payment. This source of funding is used to assist needy families with children so that children can be cared for in their own homes or in the homes of relatives; end the dependence of needy parents on government benefits by promoting job preparation, work, and marriage; prevent and reduce the incidence of out-of-wedlock pregnancies; and encourage the formation and maintenance of two-parent families. Particular transactions will report under #22a.

recipient_justification: The requested draw for Grant# 90ZU0628-02 Home Study and Post Release Services for Unaccompanied Children to reimburse funds to cover expenses for the Period of 05-01-24 to 05-31-25 not reimbursed in prior payments. These expenditures represent the costs necessary to continue to secure leased facilities with required ancillary costs to staff offices for case management and home study services in all cities nationally for 2,000 Home Study and 17,500 cases annually. These lease payments are due on the first of each month and are classified as direct OTHER costs under the terms of the contract, with $1,285,683 appropriated and authorized for this purpose in the current grant period of performance. It is also funding health insurance for staff members classified under FRINGE costs required under the Service Contract Act also due on the first of each month to which the government has appropriated and authorized $7,848,820 for this purpose in the current grant period of performance

award_description: HEAD START AND EARLY HEAD START
recipient_justification:
The purpose of this funding request is to reimburse BBI for expenditures incurred in support of the Head Start Program during March 2025. The total request amount reflects increased activity due to the addition of two new program locations and a classroom renovation. $70,111.84 was spent on classroom renovation efforts. 

Specifically, $79,248.13 is attributed to start-up costs for the new sites, Garfield and Whitlock Elementary School. These expenses include $11,658.87 in classroom expenses, like consumable education supplies to support the implementation of our evidence-based curriculum High Scope. Other costs are related to preparing the building for children with graphics, family orientation, professional development for staff about Head Start Standards and the curriculum, office supplies, and cleaning and maintenance. 

The remaining $449,698.55 represents expenditures related to routine program operations. $377,770 is related to salaries, benefits, and payroll taxes. The difference was spent on depreciation, insurance, security for the building, professional development for staff, information technology costs, and supplies needed to ensure children are safe and healthy (diapers, wipes, etc).

recipient_justification:
The Office of Head Start’s Early Head Start–Child Care Partnerships (EHS-CCP) Expansion Program is designed to expand access to high-quality early learning opportunities for infants and toddlers from low-income families. Through this initiative, grantees partner with local childcare providers to deliver comprehensive services that include health, nutrition, and developmental support.
The Los Angeles County Office of Education (LACOE) is requesting reimbursement for expenses incurred between March 28, 2025, and May 5, 2025, in support of its EHS-CCP programs. The reimbursement request covers the following cost categories:
Object 4310, Materials and Supplies: $139,221.72
Object 5110, Subgrantee Contracts over $25,000: $314,500.00
Object 5310, Dues and Memberships: -$333.50
Object 5612, Rent/Lease – Equipment: $518.16
Object 5891, Contract Services – Other Non-Instructional: $109,153.95
Object 5891, Indirect Support: $2,166.80
Total Reimbursement Requested: $565,227.13
All grantee and sub-recipient expenditures are aligned with LACOE’s goals and objectives for the 2024–2025 Program Year.
