recipient_justification:
This message provides a detailed justification for the payment request associated with Grant #90ZU060902, which funds the Long-Term Foster Care (LTFC) program for Unaccompanied Alien Children, supported by the Office of Refugee Resettlement (ORR).

The total reimbursement amount requested is $564,967.94, covering expenses incurred during the period of March 1–31, 2025.

Program Overview:
Grant #90ZU060902 supports a Long-Term Foster Care (LTFC) program, a specialized foster care model designed for Unaccompanied Alien Children (UAC) who are not currently eligible for short-term reunification due to the absence of a viable sponsor. These children remain in licensed foster homes for extended periods while pursuing immigration relief or permanency planning options. The program offers trauma-informed support, long-term stability, and a nurturing family environment to promote healing and growth.

Children in this program receive educational services, medical and mental health care, and ongoing case management. Case managers ensure that all children attend their required immigration court hearings (Notice to Appear) and that legal and permanency planning is actively maintained in compliance with ORR guidelines.

Even though the children in this program currently lack viable sponsors, our staff continues to actively search for and vet potential sponsors throughout the child’s placement, consistent with ORR’s commitment to family reunification when safe and appropriate.

The Long-Term Foster Care model is essential for children who are especially vulnerable to trafficking, exploitation, and abuse. The structure of the program—including stable placements, adult supervision, and rigorous oversight—provides a critical safety net, ensuring these children are not released into unsafe or uncertain circumstances.

Time Period Covered:
This request reflects costs incurred from March 1 to March 31, 2025.

Summary of Costs and Justification:

Salaries – $310,565.36
Supports case managers, clinicians, and other licensed professionals responsible for long-term care delivery, legal compliance, and permanency planning.

Fringe – $85,689.72
Includes employer-paid benefits such as health insurance, payroll taxes, and retirement contributions for LTFC program staff.

Supplies – $4,106.14
Covers hygiene items, clothing, school supplies, and other essentials needed for day-to-day care of children in long-term placements.

Other – $116,491.61
Includes foster parent per diems for licensed families providing extended care, as well as interpretation and other necessary non-categorized program services.

Travel – $0.00
No travel-related costs were incurred during this period.

Administrative/Indirect – $48,115.11
Covers infrastructure, compliance monitoring, IT, and general administrative support needed to operate the program effectively.

Necessity and Reasonableness:
All expenses listed are reasonable, necessary, and appropriate for the continued operation of a federally funded Long-Term Foster Care program. These costs reflect the program’s commitment to child safety, legal compliance, long-term care coordination, and sponsor identification efforts. By maintaining stable placements and consistent case management, the program prevents unnecessary transfers, protects children from trafficking risks, and provides a path toward permanency.

Alignment with Federal Priorities:
All ORR-funded programs operated by the National Youth Advocate Program, including this Long-Term Foster Care program, are implemented in accordance with federal requirements and are aligned with the President’s Executive Orders and national priorities, including:
	•	Providing care and protection for unaccompanied alien children who lack viable sponsors
	•	Preventing exploitation and trafficking through structured long-term care and supervision
	•	Ensuring full immigration court compliance and legal follow-up
	•	Supporting efficient immigration system processes while actively pursuing reunification opportunities

Please let us know if any additional information or documentation is required to support this request. We remain committed to delivering high-quality, compliant care for vulnerable children who require long-term support.
agency_lead_justification: The expenses described are consistent with the purpose of the National Youth Advocate Program, Inc. program. The expenses as described are generally reasonable for this program.

award_description: HEAD START AND EARLY HEAD START
recipient_justification:
The original request had an attached spreadsheet with the information below. For the amount requested:
1. Our bimonthly payroll for a little over 150 employees (serving over 600 children and families) averages $265,000 for a cash requirement. This amount is due on 5/10/2025
2. Our indirect payment to the company that handles the administration burden is $74,313 a month. The total fee is less than 10% of our whole grant. The amount was due on 5/1/2025
3. Our 401k payments come separately from the payroll run. This averages about $8,500 a payroll run, also due on 5/10/2025
4. The medical insurance bill for United is on average $63,000 for coverage on some of our employees. This is also due on 5/10/2025
5. We have a range of automatic ACH payments that hit our account in the first few days of the month. As of today, we have a total of $12,356.42, however, I was only requesting $10,000 to cover this. The ACH payments include for all 5 campuses: Phone, Internet, Security, Utilities, and Insurance.
6. We operate our accounts payable through a system called Airbase - this requires 2 approvers before anything can get paid. The current amount sitting in the approved queue waiting to be paid is $180,000. All of these items are due as of now(5/7/2025) and include items such as: Cleaning and supplies for campuses, Classroom supplies, including diapers, meals for children (most gets covered by state, but a portion is still remaining), some repair cost to have a working AC at one of our campuses, lawncare for our campuses, and some contractors for child behavor specialist and medical nurses.
7. Also, in the Airbase system, we have to prepay the credit cards. We like to keep $10,000 in there for incidentals.
The total for these expenses is a little over $610,000. (We round numbers down to prevent overspending of our grant, and we keep round numbers when requesting to prevent odd amounts from getting stuck in the system - we once were held up for weeks because of math errors in both of these in the Payment Management System)
Our spreadsheet also lists a $50,000 bank reserve we are required to have per our policies and procedures. This is for emergencies and is based on holding about $10,000 per campus for incidentals. The account currently is at $100,000, so our request was deducting the extra $50,000 out of the total expenses. 
The total amount requested is $560,000.
As you can see, most items are due or due in the next few days, including payroll. We currently do not have enough cash to cover payroll and are not allowed to request more than 3 days in advance. We have over 8 years of clean single audits, where the Head Start grant is selected for additional testing. I will be more than happy to supply these.

recipient_justification:
This Payment Management System (PMS) payment request is to reimburse the Louisiana Workforce Commission for pass-through disbursements made to local Community Services Block Grant (CSBG) subrecipients for the 2401LACOSR grant. These disbursements covered allowable administrative and programmatic expenses incurred in support of CSBG-funded activities, as outlined in the approved grant award.

The purpose of CSBG is to support services and activities for individuals and families with low incomes that address and alleviate the causes and conditions of poverty. States receive CSBG funds based on a statutory formula and are required to allocate 90 percent of their award to a network of local eligible entities. These entities include, but are not limited to, Community Action Agencies (CAAs), local governments, tribes and tribal organizations, and migrant and seasonal farmworker organizations.

Based on local community needs assessments, these entities provide a range of services in the areas of employment, education, income and asset building, housing, nutrition, emergency services, and healthcare. Examples of supported services include youth and adult education programs (e.g., summer learning and financial literacy classes), transportation, utility assistance, and distribution of emergency hygiene supplies.
agency_lead_justification: The expenses described are consistent with the purpose of the program. The expenses as described are generally reasonable for this program.

recipient_justification:
The request being made is for funding of payroll (BUDGET LINE PERSONNEL) and related tax and benefits payments (BUDGET LINE FRINGE) for 186 people staffing two “staff secure” shelter facilities, one in Grand Prairie, TX and one in Fairfield, CA. These funds are to pay payroll and related fringe for the period of 4-28-2025 to 5-11-2025.

The funding requested is to pay for direct labor as defined by the U.S. Department of Labor under the McNamara-O'Hara Service Contract Act (SCA) for the staff that is providing services to the unaccompanied alien children. These staff members consist of the following positions as approved and appropriated by the grant:

Case Managers, Case Aides, Clinicians, Nurse Practitioners, Nurses, Cooks, Custodians, Educational Facilitators, Crisis Response and Security, Maintenance staff, Trainers, Transporters, Medical Transcriptionists, Epidemiology staff, Sex Abuse Prevention staff, Administrative Assistants, Personnel Resources support staff, Site directors and supervisors, and logistics staff.

Total requested is as follows:
Personnel: Salaries and Wages - $404,997.06
Fringe: Payroll Taxes - $30,668.22
Fringe: State Unemployment - $637.81
Fringe: Worker’s Compensation Insurance - $7,753.06
Fringe: Retirement Expense - $13,662.06
Indirect Expense (10%) - $45,771.82

Without these professionals it would not be possible for our organization to meet the requirements of our cooperative agreement with the US Department of Health and Human Services, which could imperil the agency’s capacity and ability to respond to critical matters of national and border security.

recipient_justification:
Coastal Plain Area EOA is formally requesting reimbursement for essential operating expenses incurred by our Head Start agency from April 1 through April 22, 2025. These costs are critical to maintaining full program operations and ensuring continued delivery of high-quality early childhood education and comprehensive services to the children and families we serve. The reimbursement request includes the following key categories.
	Personnel Costs- this includes salaries and fringe benefits for all 170 employees currently employed by our agency. Our dedicated staff play essential roles in administration, education, family support, nutrition, and facilities. Maintaining this workforce is fundamental to the effective operation of our Head Start centers and to compliance with performance standards.
	Utilities and Operational Overhead – We are requesting reimbursement for utilities and related operating costs across all 13 of our centers. This includes electricity, water, gas, internet, and phone services, all of which are necessary to sustain safe, functional, and supportive environments for children, families, and staff.
	Nutrition Services- As a Head Start agency, providing well-balanced meals and snacks is an integral part of our mission. This reimbursement covers the cost of food and nutrition services that directly support the health and well-being of enrolled children, ensuring they receive the nourishment needed to optimal growth and learning.
All expenses included in the request are allowable, reasonable, and necessary in accordance with Head Start regulations and federal cost principles. Any supporting documentation is available upon request. Thank you for your continued support of our agency and the Head Start mission.
agency_lead_justification: The expenses appear to be reasonable and generally allowable for the provision of Head Start services to promote the school readiness of children from low-income families, birth to five, by fostering their cognitive, social, and emotional development through comprehensive services in early learning, health, and family well-being.

Thank you for your request for additional information regarding our recent Head Start drawdown request. I am pleased to provide the following clarification:

Time period: April 18 through April 25, 2025

Benefit Costs: $108,608.88 (health insurance, retirement contributions and payroll taxes)
Classroom supplies/facility costs/parent engagement expenses: $243,125.20 (educational materials, books, self-assessments, rent, utilities, maintenance, safety improvements, parent educational materials)

Administrative Costs: $149,771.36 (for program oversight, compliance monitoring, and required reporting)

All expenses directly support our Head Start program objectives of providing comprehensive early childhood education and family services to eligible children in our community, as outlined in our approved grant application. Each expenditure category aligns with the program performance standards and contributes to our goals of promoting school readiness and supporting child development.

Please let me know if you require any additional information or documentation to process this payment request.

Thank you.
Tracy Webster
Chief Financial Officer
(661) 336-5236, ext 1137

recipient_justification: These payments were made in accordance with our approved IV-E state plan. These payments were made to support and enhance timely permanency services for children in Pennsylvania who are in the custody of county children and youth agencies and to provide post-permanency support services to families.  Services provided include direct services such as child profile, child preparation, child specific recruitment, family profile, placement, finalization and post-permanency services.  Support services are also provided including the Pennsylvania Adoption Exchange, the Legal Services Initiative, the SWAN Helpline, training, technical assistance, conferencing, matching services and activities, the American Bar Association’s Barriers to Permanency Project, support for the Pennsylvania State Resource Family Association and public relations support.

award_description: HEAD START AND EARLY HEAD START
recipient_justification:
This draw request includes payment for a diverse range of expenses that are essential to the effective operation of our Early Head Start and Head Start programs. These costs are aligned with applicable Head Start Program Performance Standards (HSPPS) and are necessary to maintain compliance and quality service delivery.

Included in this request are:

Cleaning supplies and janitorial services, which are critical to maintaining a safe and sanitary learning environment in accordance with HSPPS 1302.47(b)(1)(i) and 1302.47(b)(2)(i).

Playground resurfacing, required to ensure safe outdoor learning and play environments, supporting HSPPS 1302.31(e)(4) and 1302.47(b)(2)(iv).

New facility signage for recently acquired sites, facilitating community awareness and accessibility, in compliance with HSPPS 1302.13.

Routine operational expenses including utility bills, rent payments, and per diem allowances for staff participating in professional development trainings and other program-related travel.

All expenditures are consistent with the approved budget and are necessary, reasonable, and allocable to the Head Start program.
agency_lead_justification: The expenses appear to be reasonable and generally allowable for the provision of Head Start services to promote the school readiness of children from low-income families, birth to five, by fostering their cognitive, social, and emotional development through comprehensive services in early learning, health, and family well-being.

Under Variation 1, DHS draws funds based on either the six-month average expenditure or one-third of the quarterly grant award—whichever is less. Fund draws are scheduled on the 15th of each month, promoting consistent monthly spending, minimizing draw frequency, and maintaining compliance with the Cash Management Improvement Act.

recipient_justification:
Justification for Reference #: 4040561616
Payee Account: 05CH012488
Subaccount: 05CH01248802

The reimbursement request associated with reference number 4040561616 pertains to the Head Start grant and covers expenses from our check run dated 05/01. These expenditures are essential to the continuous operation of our Head Start program, which provides vital early childhood education and family support services.

Specifically, the request includes (but is not limited to):

Payments to contracted Head Start partners (Colab): Supporting partner agencies that deliver direct services to children and families.

Utilities and rent for Head Start centers: Ensuring safe and accessible facilities for program operations.

Health insurance costs: Providing essential employee benefits to retain qualified staff and ensure program stability.

General program expenses: Covering necessary operational costs such as supplies, transportation, training, technology, and maintenance, all of which are crucial for maintaining program quality and compliance.

These expenses are in direct alignment with the purpose and allowable uses of federal funds under the Head Start grant and Executive Order 14222.
agency_lead_justification: The expenses described are generally reasonable and consistent with the purpose of the Head Start Grant program.

recipient_justification:
Head Start is a federally funded program that promotes the school readiness of infants, toddlers, and preschool-aged children from low-income families. Administered by the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, Head Start provides comprehensive services that support early learning, health, nutrition, and family well-being.
The program includes two main components:
Head Start (for children ages 3–5)
Early Head Start (for pregnant women, infants, and toddlers up to age 3)
In addition to educational activities that support cognitive and emotional development, Head Start emphasizes parental involvement and connects families to health care, social services, and other community resources. Its goal is to give children a strong start in life and close the opportunity gap before they enter kindergarten.
 
Additionally, the includes a health and safety supplement to address urgent health and safety needs that go beyond what’s covered in base grant.

We are requesting reimbursement for the period 03/20/2025 - 04/23/2025 for the approved budget categories in the notice of award: Salary and Wages, Fringe Benefits, Travel, Other, Supplies, Contractual and Indirect Costs.
agency_lead_justification: The expenses described are generally reasonable and consistent with the purpose of the Head Start Grant program.

recipient_justification: The Texas Family Violence Program provides funding for immediate shelter and direct services for victims of dating violence, family violence and their dependents. Funds provided through the ACF Family Violence Prevention Services Act grant and expenditures under the grant directly support state personnel and operational costs to administer and oversee the grant and provide local funding to non-profit family violence organizations to provide direct services to victims. Direct services include shelter, safety planning, counseling, information and referrals, and additional supports based on victim needs. The expenses related to this request are for this purpose and have already been incurred by the grantee or state and would be considered reimbursements for those incurred expenses. All expenses are in alignment with the federally approved budget, and in accordance with all requirements with 2 CFR 200 Subpart E.
agency_lead_justification: Expenses appear to be reasonable and allowable under FVPSA and the recipient's project.

recipient_justification: This draw request is for subaccount TANF25 the FFY 2025 Temporary Assistance for Needy Families Award. The draw request is necessary so that the Georgia Department of Human Services can continue providing monthly cash assistance payments to low-income families with children, as well as provide services that address the program's four broad purposes. The expenditures we post to this awards are allowable and within the period of availability. They include, but are not limited to: Salaries, fringe benefits, travel, direct benefits, indirect costs, contracts, and IT.
agency_lead_justification: The draw request is approved because the expenditures are allowable under the FFY 2025 TANF award, fall within the period of availability, align with ACF-196R reporting requirements, and are consistent with expenses that are reasonable for accomplishing the statutory purposes of TANF. The expenditures fall under ACF-196R line items 1 (Basic Assistance), 3 (Work-Related Activities/Expenses), 5 (Program Management), and 6 (Systems).

recipient_justification: This request seeks funding to cover the cost of four (4) buses dedicated to transporting Head Start children to and from program sites. Transportation is a critical component of the Head Start program, as it ensures consistent attendance and equitable access to early childhood education for low-income families. Many enrolled families face significant transportation challenges that would otherwise limit their children's participation. By providing safe, reliable transportation, the program supports Head Start Performance Standards related to accessibility and family engagement, while promoting school readiness and developmental outcomes for enrolled children. The addition of these buses will directly enhance service delivery and ensure that children can fully benefit from the comprehensive services offered by Head Start.
agency_lead_justification: The expenses appear to be reasonable and generally allowable for the provision of Head Start services to promote the school readiness of children from low-income families, birth to five, by fostering their cognitive, social, and emotional development through comprehensive services in early learning, health, and family well-being.

award_description: GY2023 REFUGEE SUPPORT SERVICES AND SET ASIDES
recipient_justification: This award is for the Refugee Support Services (RSS) program, funded by the Office of Refugee Resettlement (ORR). RSS is used primarily for services designed to enable ORR-eligible populations to obtain jobs within one year of enrolling in services to achieve economic self-sufficiency as soon as possible. RSS also addresses barriers to employment, such as social adjustment, interpretation, and translation. This drawdown is for the continuation of the RSS program in May for Kansas. These funds cover IRC’s RSS administrative expenses, including salaries, fringe, and associated operational costs such as facilities and equipment, and payments for RSS administrative expenses to IRC’s ten sub-awardees in New Jersey for their RSS implementation during this period

recipient_justification: Award 02CH01184304 supports funding to Acelero Learning Monmouth Middlesex and Acelero Learning Camden Philadelphia Head Start and Early Head Start programs.  In Head Start and Early Head Start programs, we provide high quality early childhood education services for low income children ages birth-to-five. The requested funds represent allowable costs incurred to operate our programs including: rent and facility costs; insurance; food service expenses, supplies, including classroom supplies, like construction paper, books, and manipulable toys; and substitute teacher staffing expenses. We require funding to compensate the teachers & faculty that run the facilities. This payroll is to be paid to employees on 05/14/25 & requires $239,172.25. We have a monthly Select Health bill that costs $85,000 - $90,000 per month to provide our employees & their families’ sufficient medical coverage.

recipient_justification: This draw request is for subaccount TANF24 the FFY 2024 Temporary Assistance for Needy Families Award. The draw request is necessary so that the Georgia Department of Human Services can continue providing monthly cash assistance payments to low-income families with children, as well as provide services that address the program's four broad purposes. The expenditures we post to this award are allowable and with the period of availability. They include, but are not limited to: Salaries, fringe benefits, travel, publications, direct benefits, indirect costs, contracts, and IT.
agency_lead_justification: The draw request is approved because the expenditures are allowable under the FFY 2025 TANF award, fall within the period of availability, align with ACF-196R reporting requirements, and are consistent with expenses that are reasonable for accomplishing the statutory purposes of TANF. The expenditures fall under ACF-196R line items 1 (Basic Assistance), 3 (Work-Related Activities/Expenses), 5 (Program Management), and 6 (Systems).

award_description: HEAD START AND EARLY HEAD START
recipient_justification: This payment request is for the Head Start Operating Grant awarded by the Administration for Children and Families, Division of Early Childhood Development, to WCCA, Inc.  for the grant period 7/01/2024 - 6/30/2025 Grant Award Number 04CH011737-05. This grant is intended to support the provision of comprehensive Head Start services to eligible preschool children and their families in Henderson, Transylvania, Rutherford and Polk Counties, in accordance with the Head Start Act and applicable regulations. This payment request seeks reimbursement for the balance of expenses incurred during the month of April 2025. These expenses, including two payrolls, fringe benefits, rents, contractual payments and other operating costs, are essential for the continued operation of our Head Start program and directly support the delivery of comprehensive services to the children and families of East Flat Rock. The key categories of expenditures included in this reimbursement request are as follows: personnel expenses and allocated fringe benefits; classroom supplies; monthly allocation of facilities and IT support; monthly contractual cost such as utilities, communications and cleaning cost. These expenditures were directly incurred in the month of April to maintain daily operations of our Head Start program.
agency_lead_justification: The expense(s) described are generally reasonable and consistent with the purpose of the Head Start Grant program.

recipient_justification:
As of April 16, 2025, the Maternity Care Coalition (MCC) Early Head Start (EHS) Program has incurred a total of $540,993 in salaries, fringe benefits, and operational expenses under Subaccount 03CH01192105. These costs reflect necessary and ongoing program activities to support families and children in alignment with Early Head Start objectives. A partial drawdown of $168,559 was submitted in March 2025 to cover a portion of these expenses.

We are now requesting reimbursement of the remaining $372,429.00 to cover additional payroll and operating costs. These expenditures are allowable, reasonable, and consistent with the approved program budget. Prompt reimbursement will ensure the MCC EHS program can continue to operate effectively and meet the needs of the families it serves.

award_description: HEAD START AND EARLY HEAD START
recipient_justification: The Head Start grant authorized by the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) is awarded to support early childhood education programs aimed at promoting the school readiness of young children from low-income families. What the award is for: The Head Start grant funds early childhood education, health, nutrition, and parent involvement services to children ages 3-5. The goal is to provide comprehensive support to ensure that children have a strong foundation for learning and development as they enter school. What the funds will be used for: The funds will be used to operate Head Start program, which includes hiring qualified staff, purchasing educational materials, providing health screenings, delivering meals, and offering family support services. The grant also supports necessary infrastructure improvements to create safe, effective learning environments. award_description: GY 2022 REFUGEE SUPPORT SERVICES AND SET ASIDES
recipient_justification: This award is for the Refugee Support Services (RSS) program, funded by the Office of Refugee Resettlement (ORR). RSS is used primarily for services designed to enable ORR-eligible populations to obtain jobs within one year of enrolling in services to achieve economic self-sufficiency as soon as possible. RSS also addresses barriers to employment, such as social adjustment, interpretation, and translation. This drawdown is for the continuation of the RSS program in April for New Jersey. These funds cover IRC’s RSS administrative expenses, including salaries, fringe, and associated operational costs such as facilities and equipment, and payments for RSS administrative expenses to IRC’s ten sub-awardees in New Jersey for their RSS implementation during this period
agency_lead_justification: The expenses described are consistent with the purpose of the RSS program. The expenses as described are generally reasonable for this program.

recipient_justification: This draw request is for subaccount AA25 the FFY 2025 The Title IV-E Adoption Assistance Award. The draw request is necessary so that the Georgia Department of Human Services can continue to provide services and programs for the adoption of children with special needs who cannot be reunited with their families and who meet certain eligibility tests. This assistance is intended to prevent long stays in foster care and to promote the healthy development of children through increased safety, permanency, and well-being. The expenditures we post to this award are allowable and within the period of 04.01.2025 - 04.30.2025. They include, but are not limited to: Advertising, direct benefits, and contracts.
agency_lead_justification: The expenses appear consistent with the purpose of the title IV-E adoption assistance.  Additional supporting documentation of the expenditures are coordinated by the submission of the CB-496 form.

recipient_justification: Maryville Academy requests payment under grant 90ZU051502 to cover approved program expenses incurred from 3/1/2025 to 3/31/2025, in support of its ORR-funded shelter for unaccompanied children. The funding supports a range of critical services including staffing such as bilingual case managers, youth care workers, and licensed clinicians along with medical and mental health care, educational programming, daily living supplies, food and hygiene products, and facility operations. The total amount requested is $360,098.86, includes $19,671.17 personnel, $44,654.99 fringe benefits, $32,997.27 supplies, $87,296.19 other program-related expenses, and $175,479.24 indirect costs. These approved costs ensure that Maryville can continue to provide a safe environment of unaccompanied children. Timely reimbursement is critical to sustaining program integrity, ensuring compliance with federal standards, promoting the safety, and successful placement of unaccompanied children in Maryville’s care
agency_lead_justification: The expenses described are consistent with the purpose of the MARYVILLE ACADEMY program. The expenses as described are generally reasonable for this program.

award_description: HEAD START AND EARLY HEAD START
recipient_justification:
Under Section 638 of the Head Start Act, these funds awarded to Tri-County CAA includes funds for budget period 01-01-2025-02-28-2026 for the operation of a Head Start Preschool and Early Head Start program in its designated areas of Johnston, North Providence, Smithfield, Burrillville, Foster, Gloster, Scituate and North Smithfield and in North Kingstown, South Kingstown, Westerly, Charlestown, Richmond, Hopkinton, Exeter, Narragansett, and New Shoreham (Block Island). The projected annual funding levels based on the application submitted for this period are $3,079, 153 for Head Start Preschool Operations; and $1,316,298 for Early Head Start Operations.  For T&TA a total of $30,793 was funded for Head Start Pre-School; and $24,530 for Early Head Start. Enrolment for Head Start Pre-School is set at 136 children, and for Early Head Start enrollment is set at 44 infants, toddlers and pregnant women. This NOA Action approves the enrollment reduction in Head Start Pre-School (as cited above), pursuant to Section 640(g)(3) of the Head Start Act, effective March 1, 2025. 

Funds spent to date for March 1, 2025 through March 31, 2025 include the following: 
Salaries: $327,272; Fringe Benefits: $80,115; Food Service Contracting (above and beyond USDA reimbursement): $5,467; Office Supplies: 1,888; Program Supplies: $19,023; Total Dues, Subscriptions: $6,931; Total Telephone: $1,927; No Travel Expenses; Outreach/Advertising/Recruitment: $420; Education and Training: $6,065; Equipment and Vehicle Expenses: $2,335; Insurance: $3,145; Facility Costs: $32,571; Utilities: $14,900; Federally Approved Indirect Cost Rate (14%) $44,197
agency_lead_justification: The expenses appear to be reasonable and generally allowable for the provision of Head Start services to promote the school readiness of children from low-income families, birth to five, by fostering their cognitive, social, and emotional development through comprehensive services in early learning, health, and family well-being.

This 90ZU062502 payment request is for our Home Study and Post Release program with a budget period of 1/1/25-12/31/25; the payment request is for program operational expenditures to run our Home Study and Post Release program and are within our approved budgeted object class categories of Personnel, Fringe Benefits, Supplies, Contractual, Other, and Indirect. The time period of expenditures is predominantly from the second half of April 2025 and does not include any Unliquidated Obligations; prior Unliquidated Obligations from the budget period of 1/1/25-12/31/25 that have since been paid, are now included.

These operational expenditures are necessary in order to support day-to-day activities of the Home Study and Post Release program.  Expenses in this payment request are broken down into the following: the workforce staffing the program, associated workforce taxes and benefits, program supplies, contracted services (interpretation and translation of less common languages and dialects), other (building and utility expenses, information technology infrastructure, travel expenses for home study and post release visits, staff training), and indirect costs. 

All current unliquidated obligations have been removed from the totals and the payment request for those expenditures will happen in subsequent periods once Morrison Child and Family Services has made payment.
agency_lead_justification: The expenses described are consistent with the purpose of the Morrison Child & Family Services program. The expenses as described are generally reasonable for this program.

award_description: HEAD START AND EARLY HEAD START
recipient_justification:
In addition to the supporting documents, payment request for the funds are necessary to reimburse Early Education and Care for expenses incurred in March. As part of the Head Start and Early Head Start program for our area, we provide educational and social services (school readiness) for the children of low-income families. Aligned with this mission and in service of this mission, we incur expenses that are needed to carry out the daily activities of this program, in service of these children. The expenses we incurred and are seeking reimbursement occurred in March and include, but are not limited to, salaries for teachers, support staff and administration, fringe for said staff, supplies to carry out the mission of the Head Start program, contractual services needed to carry out the individual programs within Head Start, and other costs, both direct and indirect needed to fulfill the mission on a daily basis (ex – rent, utilities, administrative overhead, travel, nutritional services, audit, and training/professional development services, among others). Further detail of the exact expenses of each line item for the remainder of March can be found below from the Expense/Revenue Statement (MIP generated). Thank you for your consideration. recipient_justification: This is a payment request from the TANF grant for the reimbursement of expenditures incurred on the previous work day.  TANF (Temporary Assistance for Needy Families) provides funds to states to design and operate programs aimed at helping low-income families with children achieve economic security and stability, with a focus on promoting work and self-sufficiency.  The request is to reimburse expenditures paid for Line 9c-work activities (including case management), Line 16-supportive services (including subgrantee payments for support services), Line 19-fatherhood and two parent family formation and maintenance (including subgrantee payments for preventive services), Line 20c-child welfare services (including social worker provider), Line 22-administration, and Line 22c-systems (including ADP operations and development).
agency_lead_justification:
The expenses described are consistent with those that are reasonable for accomplishing the statutory purposes of TANF.

recipient_justification:
The Child Care Subsidy program provides financial assistance low-income families to access child care so they can work or attend a job training or educational program. In addition, the program also supports investments in quality child care programs and providers, including high skills and qualifications for child care workforce, high quality standards, and other opportunities that increase quality across the early childhood spectrum. 
This request is to reimburse the costs of child care subsidy payments for low income families who are eligible for child care subsidy to assist in covering the costs of child care for the children in their family. In addition, these funds will pay for the costs of the contracts and agreements that the Child Care Subsidy program currently has to increase quality measures within the early childhood spectrum in Nebraska. Finally, the costs will support the administration of the Child Care Subsidy program including licensing staff, resource development staff and program staff who are ensuring that the Child Care subsidy program is operating appropriately and as required to meet federal requirements of the program.
agency_lead_justification: Expenditures appear consistent with grant purposes as described by the grantee.

recipient_justification: This request covers June 1, 2024 through March 31, 2025 for our Year 1 activities which were carried forward for 90YE0359 (previously 90YE0300) “Unequal Burdens, Unequal Access?  Understanding How Administrative Burden Mediates Payment and Co-Payment Policies” and our Year 2 activities through March 31, 2025. We gathered CDC Scholarship program documents for administrative complexity analysis; convened two advisory groups quarterly; met with our state partner team monthly; participated in COP and related meetings; and obtained direct feedback from providers, eligibility specialists, and parents who were part of the state’s pilot to expand access to infant/toddler child care slots. We disseminated study findings in June 2024, October 2024, November 2024, and March 2025. Costs included labor, travel for a presentation, supplies, graphic design, transcription, and compensation for families' and providers’ time and efforts in participating in interviews and responding to surveys

recipient_justification:
We have received NOAs indicating Dept of Health and Human Services, Admin for Children and Families, Office of Head Start approval for improvements related to one of our educational centers that serves children. The NOA authorizing these expenses are NOA  08CH011738-03-04 and NOA 08CH011738-05-01. These NOAs authorized $1.3 million to expand our education center called Echo Academy or Echo Campus to expand to accommodate an additional classroom, safety improvements, transportation and maintenance office/storage space. We waited for Region VIII to approve a budget revision going back to the funding period 2022-23. It was finally approved in Nov 2024 and approved to carry over into the current budget year 2024-25. 

We have spent $325,590.73 in February and in March 2025 thus far in safety improvements and the construction  of the new classroom. These are our out-of-pocket expenses for approved items detailed in our NOAs. We are asking for the funds to reimburse these expenses made thus far in this ongoing construction phase and improvements. Thank you!

recipient_justification: This is a payment request from the TANF grant for the reimbursement of expenditures incurred on the previous work day.  TANF (Temporary Assistance for Needy Families) provides funds to states to design and operate programs aimed at helping low-income families with children achieve economic security and stability, with a focus on promoting work and self-sufficiency.  The request is to reimburse expenditures paid for Line 9c-work activities (including case management), Line 16-supportive services (including subgrantee payments for support services), Line 19-fatherhood and two parent family formation and maintenance (including subgrantee payments for preventive services), Line 20c-child welfare services (including social worker provider), Line 22-administration, and Line 22c-systems (including ADP operations and development).

agency_lead_justification:
The expenses described are consistent with those that are reasonable for accomplishing the statutory purposes of TANF.

award_description: HEAD START AND EARLY HEAD START
recipient_justification: This draw request supports essential operational expenses for our Early Head Start and Head Start programs, aligned with Head Start Program Performance Standards (HSPPS) to ensure compliance and quality services. Covered costs include alarm system services to maintain facility safety and emergency preparedness (HSPPS 1302.47(b)(1)(v)), rent for appropriate, accessible learning environments (HSPPS 1302.21(d)(1)), utilities to ensure safe, functional program operations (HSPPS 1302.47(b)(1)(i)), pest control to uphold health and sanitation standards (HSPPS 1302.47(b)(2)(i)), and per diems for staff attending trainings and program-related travel (HSPPS 1302.92(b)). All expenses are necessary, reasonable, allocable, and consistent with the approved budget.

award_description: HEAD START AND EARLY HEAD START
recipient_justification:
This fund request is to reimburse Early Education and Care / Head Start for expenses incurred in March, prior to closing Month end to allow upcoming payroll to be processed. Once March is closed (roughly 04/24/25), a much smaller amount will be requested for any remaining expenses incurred during March, thus truing up March and closing.

The organization's previous Finance Director's system for determining drawdown amounts was not able to be determined. I am the new CFO for Head Start and as such, am creating a consistent method of requests. This method is as follows: 

Previous method - not determined.

Current Method - on/around mid-month a revenue/expense report will be generated showing all current expenses incurred by the Head Start program for the previous month. A request for payment will then be submitted at that time. One week later, after the previous month has been finalized and closed, a request for payment will be submitted in the amount of the balance (much smaller) of remaining expenses from the previous month.

Note - I joined this organization in February, and when analyzing expense reports, it appears the funding previously requested for February did not match the total February expenses. An addendum request for reimbursement of the balance of February's expenses will also be made to correct and true up through the end of February. Expense documents can be provided to show the discrepancies.
agency_lead_justification: The expenses described are generally reasonable and consistent with the purpose of the Head Start Grant program.

For future submissions, please clearly indicate the applicable ACF-196R line item, such as: Line 6 – Basic Assistance; Line 6a – Basic Assistance (excluding foster care and adoption/guardianship subsidies), or; Line 6b – Relative Foster Care Maintenance Payments and Adoption/Guardianship Subsidies. Using this level of clarity will help ensure timely review and processing moving forward.

recipient_justification:
The McPherson-Marion County Head Start program is requesting a $293,352.57 payment for the March 1, 2025 - April 30, 2025 period to support several areas of the program’s operation.

A large portion of the request, $178,181.20, will go toward instructional costs including classroom staff salaries, benefits, and supplies used for teaching. The program is also requesting $100 for drug testing required during pre-employment screening. Social work services, including the salary and benefits of the program's social worker, account for $12,099.56.

To meet health and safety standards, $1,047.92 is requested for medical services and supplies. For instructional improvements—such as the salaries and benefits of education coordinators and coaches, along with training and technical help—$12,367.52 is needed. General administration costs, including salaries and benefits for the director, coordinators, and administrative assistant, and program supplies, total $49,704.16.

Additionally, $19,526.44 is for parent services including the salaries and benefits of family advocates and supplies used to support families.  Cell phone service for advocates amount to $473.49. Automotive costs for vehicle insurance come to $629.96, while transportation costs, including fuel and field trips, are $438.21. Finally, $18,784.11 is for food services to provide meals and snacks.
agency_lead_justification: The expenses appear to be reasonable and generally allowable for the provision of Head Start services to promote the school readiness of children from low-income families, birth to five, by fostering their cognitive, social, and emotional development through comprehensive services in early learning, health, and family well-being.

award_description: HEAD START AND EARLY HEAD START
recipient_justification:
Per their website….

Working with the Teaching Strategies Curriculum:
 
IgniteTable by Hatch™ provides a collaborative learning experience where children engage with peers while building prosocial, communication, and cooperative learning skills. As young learners play, IgniteTable automatically captures authentic work samples and data, allowing teachers to spend less time administering assessments and more time supporting the development of essential prosocial skills that set children up for success in school and beyond. As the table captures data, it is uploaded into the Creative Curriculum assessment tool called GOLD. This enables teachers to gather more information about a child’s learning. Then teachers can use the data to individualize for each child to support their continued development and learning by planning for the next steps.

Linda Wright
Head Start Education Manager

Mobile: 585-305-0298

Address: 400 West Avenue, Rochester NY 14611
Web: www.abcinfo.org

recipient_justification: Pennsylvania Temporary Assistance for Needy Families program. These funds provide time-limited cash payments, vouchers and other forms of benefits designed to meet a family’s ongoing basic needs (i.e., for food, clothing, shelter, utilities, household goods, personal care items and general incidental expenses). To provide needy families with funds to meet basic living expenses.
agency_lead_justification:
Thank you for your submission. The description provided aligns with the purpose of the Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF) program and supports the provision of time-limited assistance to help families meet their basic living needs.

For future submissions, please be sure to include the corresponding ACF-196R line item number and category (e.g., Line 6 – Basic Assistance), as this helps expedite review and ensures consistency with federal reporting requirements. General descriptions such as cash payments, vouchers, and essential needs (food, clothing, shelter, etc.) fall under Basic Assistance when they directly address a family’s ongoing needs.

Thank you, and please continue to submit claims with this level of specificity.

recipient_justification:
Award 21PCMNCDC6  is ARPA Child Care and Development Fund (CCDF). This is the primary federal funding source to help certain families with low incomes access child care and to improve the quality of child care for all children. As a block grant, CCDF gives funding to States, Territories, and Tribes to provide child care subsidies primarily through vouchers or certificates to families with low income. In addition, CCDF funds are used to improve the quality of child care for both subsidized and unsubsidized children. CCDF consists of both Discretionary funding authorized by the Child Care and Development Block Grant (CCDBG) Act and Mandatory and Matching funding under the Social Security Act. In addition to the block grants to States, Territories and Tribes, a small portion of the CCDF is used by the Office of Child Care to provide technical assistance to lead agencies on administering the program. A small portion of CCDF is also used for child care research, demonstration and evaluation, and federal administration activities.

The funds will be used to reimburse the grant for expenses incurred that align with White Earth's CCDF plan. 
The expenses being reimbursed fall into the below categories:
Child Care- $21,200.31
Admin- $32,856.37
Non-Direct- $20,614.24
Quality- $200,025.40
Infant/Toddler Quality- $11,329.69
Total $286,026

These expenses are necessary to carry out the programmatic functions of the CCDF grant which provides essential child care services to the White Earth reservation.
agency_lead_justification: Expenditures appear consistent with grant purposes as described by the grantee.

award_description: HEAD START AND EARLY HEAD START
recipient_justification:
In general, the overall award as described in Notice of Award for Award # 03CH012721-01-00 is to operate Head Start (HS) and Early Head Start (EHS) programs in counties in north central West Virginia from a delegate in Monongalia county to direct operations from Marion County down to Webster County. These specific funds being requested from this draw are to reimburse North Central WV Community Action Association (NCWVCAA) for activities that took place since the last draw on 3/31/25. 
$217,111 will be spent on payroll date 4/17/25 (correction from payroll date 4/14/25) to cover salaries and fringe benefits of 130 employees who worked HS hours between 3/27/25 to 4/9/25. $24,425 will be spent on payroll date 4/17/25 to cover salaries and fringe benefits of 28 employees who worked EHS hours between 3/27/25 to 4/9/25. Fringe Benefits include employer FICA taxes, employer portion of Health Insurance provided, employer match to 403b retirement contribution, WV Workers Compensation insurance, and WV Unemployment taxes as required by WV law. Annual Leave is a benefit due to employees to cover paid time off and vacation or be paid directly to employees upon termination from the company. Generally Accepted Accounting Principles (GAAP) requires accrued liabilities to be taken for employee owed paid time off such as our Annual Leave. 
$7,237 and $1,202 for HS and EHS respectively was spent on classroom supplies and food to operate services to students and parents. $23,664 and $3,124 for HS and EHS respectively to cover building maintenance cost such as rent, utilities, cleaning, and general maintenance items. $7,506 and $864 for HS and EHS respectively to cover travel and meeting costs of Program Specialists and parent liaisons with classrooms and parents as well as T&TA activities.
agency_lead_justification: The expenses appear to be reasonable and generally allowable for the provision of Head Start services to promote the school readiness of children from low-income families, birth to five, by fostering their cognitive, social, and emotional development through comprehensive services in early learning, health, and family well-being.

recipient_justification:
The total amount of $268,449.59 requested, is used to reimburse two critical vendors who serve pregnant women and their families in Baltimore City.   The first provider, HealthCare Access Maryland, works in partnership with the Baltimore City Health Department to reduce infant and maternal mortality through the nationally recognized initiative, B'more for Healthy Babies (BHB). HCAM operates BHB’s citywide centralized intake system for pregnant women and infants, serving as the single point of entry for: 
(1) home visiting services, (2) health insurance and nine managed care organizations, (3) obstetric and pediatric services, (4) behavioral health services, (5) nutrition services, (6) and other supports in the system.  The second provider, the Family League of Baltimore, spearheads BHB’s community engagement work, overseeing the contracts for two BHB Community Sites, designing and implementing BHB’s faith-based outreach strategy, and managing BHB’s Community Advisory Board. In addition, Family League oversees several home visiting providers in the city, and works closely with BCHD, HealthCare Access Maryland (HCAM), and Baltimore City Public Schools to place Community Health Advocates in several of the city’s community action centers.

These funds are critical and contributing to the reduction of infant mortality in the City and more efficient and effective service delivery for families with pregnant women and infants.

We certify that these costs are reasonable, necessary, allocable, and allowable under the terms of the award.

Best regards,
Joseph

recipient_justification:
This message provides a detailed justification for the payment request associated with Grant #90ZU056802, which funds the Long-Term Foster Care (LTFC) program for Unaccompanied Alien Children, supported by the Office of Refugee Resettlement (ORR).

The total reimbursement amount requested is $260,974.66, covering expenses incurred during the period of March 1–31, 2025.

Program Overview:
Grant #90ZU056802 supports a Long-Term Foster Care (LTFC) program, a specialized foster care model designed for Unaccompanied Alien Children (UAC) who are not currently eligible for short-term reunification due to the absence of a viable sponsor. These children remain in licensed foster homes for extended periods while pursuing immigration relief or permanency planning options. The program provides consistent, trauma-informed support, educational services, and a stable family environment to promote healing and long-term well-being.

This LTFC program operates in Illinois, with a licensed bed capacity of 96. While in care, children receive comprehensive support including medical, mental health, education, and long-term case management services. Critically, case managers ensure children are informed of and attend all required immigration court hearings (Notice to Appear), in full compliance with federal immigration processes.

While these children do not currently have viable sponsors, our team continues to actively search for and vet potential sponsors throughout the child’s placement. These ongoing efforts reflect our commitment to reunification whenever safely and appropriately possible, in accordance with ORR’s priorities.

Children in long-term care are particularly vulnerable to trafficking and exploitation. By providing structured, licensed family-based placements and continuous oversight, this program significantly reduces the risk of trafficking, ensuring children are not released into unsafe or unstable conditions during a critical phase in their immigration journey.

Time Period Covered:
This request reflects costs incurred from March 1 to March 31, 2025.

Summary of Costs and Justification:

Salaries – $157,705.16
Supports licensed staff including case managers, clinicians, and program supervisors responsible for long-term care coordination, legal follow-up, and permanency planning.

Fringe – $42,042.47
Includes employer-paid benefits such as payroll taxes, health insurance, and retirement contributions for long-term care program staff.

Supplies – $2,048.43
Covers basic necessities for long-term care placements including hygiene products, bedding, educational materials, and clothing.

Other – $21,427.33
Includes foster parent per diems paid to licensed caregivers providing long-term placements, as well as interpretation services and other essential program support costs.

Travel – $0.00
No travel expenses were incurred during this reporting period.

Administrative/Indirect – $37,751.27
Supports infrastructure, IT, compliance, and administrative oversight required to sustain a high-quality long-term foster care program.

Necessity and Reasonableness:
All expenses included in this payment request are reasonable, necessary, and appropriate to the ongoing operation of a federally funded Long-Term Foster Care program. The costs reflect the core supports necessary to care for children without immediate reunification options while continuing efforts to identify potential sponsors and prepare for permanency planning.

The program ensures that children are placed in safe, licensed homes, that their legal and developmental needs are met, and that they are protected from trafficking and unsafe discharge situations through structured care and oversight.

Alignment with Federal Priorities:
All ORR-funded programs operated by the National Youth Advocate Program, including this Long-Term Foster Care program, are implemented in accordance with federal regulations and align with the President’s Executive Orders and national priorities, including:
	•	Providing continued care and protection for unaccompanied alien children who lack viable sponsors
	•	Preventing exploitation and trafficking through long-term placement and supervision
	•	Ensuring immigration court compliance and legal follow-through
	•	Supporting efficient immigration system processes while actively pursuing reunification opportunities

Please let us know if any additional information or documentation is required to support this request. We remain committed to ensuring quality care, legal compliance, and protective oversight for children in our long-term foster care program.

Total Reimbursement Request: $260,974.66
agency_lead_justification: The expenses described are consistent with the purpose of the National Youth Advocate Program, Inc. program. The expenses as described are generally reasonable for this program.

recipient_justification:
This draw request includes payment for a diverse range of expenses that are essential to the effective operation of our Early Head Start and Head Start programs. These costs are aligned with applicable Head Start Program Performance Standards (HSPPS) and are necessary to maintain compliance and quality service delivery.

Included in this request are:

Cleaning supplies and janitorial services, which are critical to maintaining a safe and sanitary learning environment in accordance with HSPPS 1302.47(b)(1)(i) and 1302.47(b)(2)(i).

Playground resurfacing, required to ensure safe outdoor learning and play environments, supporting HSPPS 1302.31(e)(4) and 1302.47(b)(2)(iv).

New facility signage for recently acquired sites, facilitating community awareness and accessibility, in compliance with HSPPS 1302.13.

Routine operational expenses including utility bills, rent payments, and per diem allowances for staff participating in professional development trainings and other program-related travel.

All expenditures are consistent with the approved budget and are necessary, reasonable, and allocable to the Head Start program.
agency_lead_justification: The expenses appear to be reasonable and generally allowable for the provision of Head Start services to promote the school readiness of children from low-income families, birth to five, by fostering their cognitive, social, and emotional development through comprehensive services in early learning, health, and family well-being.

recipient_justification: Purpose of the Funds Request This justification outlines the need for requesting funds from the Payment Management System (PMS) to cover allowable expenditures for five grants under the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (DHHS) Office of Head Start. The funds requested are necessary to maintain continuous operations and services that directly support the delivery of high-quality early childhood education and family services. Specifically, the requested funds will cover multiple categories of expenditures, including payroll, employee health benefits, facility operations, transportation, professional services, and programmatic support costs incurred or anticipated for the periods ending April 30, 2025, and May 1, 2025. These costs are consistent with the approved budgets for each grant and are essential for uninterrupted service delivery to enrolled children, families, and program staff. Detailed Justification of Expenditures 1.	Payroll Costs – Pay Period Ending April 18, 2025

The CT Children's  Medical Center  houses the The Child Abuse Centers of Excellence (CACE) service provides an array of expert medical services to children who are suspected of being victims of abuse or neglect and to their families by acting as expert consultants to the Department of Children and Families (Department or DCF) staff to help ensure the safety and well-being of children.  They provide 500 slots per year - funding was for the quarter ending 3.31.25 for 172 slots used during that period. The Connection provides supportive housing for 206 families per year. Calculation is based on 15% deMinimus of total modified direct expenses. recipient_justification:
This request is for the expenses related to HS/EHS operations that were submitted from our 13 locations between April 20, 2025 - April 26, 2025.  It includes expenses such as Utilities, employee expenses, Program & Office Supplies for centers, etc. related to operations of our facilities.  This request is a replacement for the request #4040561034 submitted originally on 4/30/25 and was listed as in transit but not paid for more than a week.  We contacted PMS concerning the delay and were informed that the 4/30/25 request was sitting there because someone mistook it for a future payment not to made until 2026.  We deleted that transaction in PMS and then resubmitted it for processing.    Listed below is the excel spreadsheet of our check register for 5/1/25.  The grand total of the Head Start check writing was $301,197.90 and it was offset by the State Early Childhood Education Revenue received of $50,110.56.  The grand total of the Head Start expenses remaining to be paid was $251,087. 34.

recipient_justification:
This Payment Management System (PMS) payment request is to reimburse the Louisiana Workforce Commission for pass-through disbursements made to local Community Services Block Grant (CSBG) subrecipients. These disbursements covered allowable administrative and programmatic expenses incurred in support of CSBG-funded activities, as outlined in the approved grant award.

The purpose of CSBG is to support services and activities for individuals and families with low incomes that address and alleviate the causes and conditions of poverty. States receive CSBG funds based on a statutory formula and are required to allocate 90 percent of their award to a network of local eligible entities. These entities include, but are not limited to, Community Action Agencies (CAAs), local governments, tribes and tribal organizations, and migrant and seasonal farmworker organizations.

Based on local community needs assessments, these entities provide a range of services in the areas of employment, education, income and asset building, housing, nutrition, emergency services, and healthcare. Examples of supported services include youth and adult education programs (e.g., summer learning and financial literacy classes), transportation, utility assistance, and distribution of emergency hygiene supplies.
agency_lead_justification: The expenses described are consistent with the purpose of the program. The expenses as described are generally reasonable for this program.

recipient_justification: LIHEAP provides low income Oregonians assistance with their home energy expenses. The LIHEAP program includes bill payment assistance, energy education, case management, and home weatherization services.  Households wishing to apply for assistance from the Oregon LIHEAP program must be at or below 60 percent of state median income. All components of Oregon’s LIHEAP program are administered through local Community Action Agencies (CAAs) in geographically accessible locations across the state. This payment reimburses the CAAs for program expenditures already incurred during the state FY25 Q3 & Q4.

recipient_justification: Funding is requested for foster care maintenance and administrative costs for eligible children placed in licensed foster care settings. Maintenance costs include food, clothing, shelter, daily supervision, personal incidentals, and school-related expenses necessary to ensure the well-being of children in care. Administrative costs cover case management activities, eligibility determinations, development and operation of the Comprehensive Child Welfare Information System (CCWIS), and placement services conducted by qualified agency staff. These funds are essential to maintain safety, permanency, and well-being goals for children in accordance with federal IV-E guidelines. Payment ensures continued compliance with state and federal mandates while supporting the delivery of timely and appropriate services to children and families.
agency_lead_justification: The expenses appear consistent with the purpose of the title IV-E foster care.  Additional supporting documentation of the expenditures are coordinated by the submission of the CB-496 form.

award_description: HEAD START AND EARLY HEAD START
recipient_justification: This draw request covers payroll expenses that are essential to the continued delivery of comprehensive services under our Early Head Start and Head Start grant. Specifically, the requested funds support compensation for instructional staff, family service workers, health and nutrition personnel, and program management—all of whom are directly responsible for implementing services required under the Head Start Program Performance Standards (HSPPS), including child development (1302.31), family engagement (1302.50), health and safety (1302.47), and program oversight (1302.101). These roles are critical to meeting staffing ratios, maintaining service continuity, and ensuring compliance with federal standards. The expenses are fully aligned with the approved budget and directly support the purposes of the grant.

recipient_justification:
The Child Care Subsidy program provides financial assistance low-income families to access child care so they can work or attend a job training or educational program. In addition, the program also supports investments in quality child care programs and providers, including high skills and qualifications for child care workforce, high quality standards, and other opportunities that increase quality across the early childhood spectrum. 
This request is to reimburse the costs of child care subsidy payments for low income families who are eligible for child care subsidy to assist in covering the costs of child care for the children in their family. In addition, these funds will pay for the costs of the contracts and agreements that the Child Care Subsidy program currently has to increase quality measures within the early childhood spectrum in Nebraska. Finally, the costs will support the administration of the Child Care Subsidy program including licensing staff, resource development staff and program staff who are ensuring that the Child Care subsidy program is operating appropriately and as required to meet federal requirements of the program.
agency_lead_justification: Expenditures appear consistent with grant purposes as described by the grantee.

The purpose of CSBG is to support services and activities for individuals and families with low incomes that address and alleviate the causes and conditions of poverty. States receive CSBG funds based on a statutory formula and are required to allocate 90 percent of their award to a network of local eligible entities. These entities include, but are not limited to, Community Action Agencies (CAAs), local governments, tribes and tribal organizations, and migrant and seasonal farmworker organizations.

recipient_justification: This request seeks reimbursement for expenses incurred from 3/1/25–3/31/25 to maintain operations at our 9-bed shelter during a zero-census period. Though unoccupied, the shelter remained staffed and operational to ensure readiness for new referrals. Reimbursable expenses include: Personnel ($182,365) – to uphold staffing ratios, perform maintenance, and ensure compliance; Other Costs ($22,126) – such as utilities to maintain safe, habitable conditions; insurance and vehicle costs. Supplies ($1,696) – including educational materials and cleaning supplies for preparedness and sanitation. An Indirect Cost of 10% on the $206,187 total = $20,619. These costs were essential to preserve program integrity, meet contractual and regulatory obligations, and maintain immediate readiness. Continued investment in staffing and facility upkeep ensures seamless transitions for incoming residents.

recipient_justification: This is a payment request from the TANF grant for the reimbursement of expenditures incurred on the previous work day. The request is to reimburse expenditures paid for Line 9c-work activities (including case management), Line 16-supportive services (including subgrantee payments for support services), Line 19-fatherhood and two parent family formation and maintenance (including subgrantee payments for preventive services), Line 20c-child welfare services (including social worker provider), Line 22-administration, and Line 22c-systems (including ADP operations and development).

recipient_justification: The March 2025 Matching Grant (MG) payment request seeks to cover program-related expenses, including personnel, fringe benefits, travel, professional fees, office and client support costs, and indirect expenses. The MG program aims to help eligible clients achieve early employment and self-sufficiency within 240 days without accessing public cash assistance. Key objectives include maintaining approved site designs and budgets, providing training and technical assistance, monitoring program compliance, managing finances per federal requirements, and submitting timely reports to ORR. The program also delivering case management and employment services, offering core maintenance support, coordinating additional services (ESL, healthcare, job training, social adjustment), tracking client outcomes, and ensuring accurate financial reporting to ECDC.
agency_lead_justification: The expenses described are consistent with the purpose of the program. The expenses as described are generally reasonable for this program.

award_description: HEAD START AND EARLY HEAD START
recipient_justification: Award 05CH01236801 supports funding to Acelero Learning Wisconsin Head Start and Early Head Start programs in Milwaukee County.  In Head Start and Early Head Start programs, we provide high quality early childhood education services for low income children ages birth-to-five.  The requested funds represent allowable personnel costs for the second half of April 2025 incurred to operate our programs including salaries, 401k contributions, and payroll taxes for teachers, aides, and staff who are directly involved in implementing and overseeing the program’s services. This funding is required to maintain program operations in accordance with grant guidelines and our approved budget.
agency_lead_justification: The expenses described are generally reasonable and consistent with the purpose of the Head Start Grant program.

recipient_justification: While drawing our payroll funds on April 17, 2025 we inadvertently drew from grant funds from the previous budget year April 1, 2024 through March 31, 2025. Since these payroll funds were for the period April 1, 2025 to April 15, 2025, they should have been drawn from the grant number associated with the new budget year that began April 1, 2025. Therefore, we are correcting the draw by returning the funds into the budget year April 1, 2024 to March 31, 2025 and drawing from the new budget year that began April 1, 2025. Again, these are direct payroll salaries, payroll taxes and benefit expenses approved for this Head Start grant.  Teachers, Teacher aides, Bus Drivers, Bus Aids, and other approved Head Start support staff.  The expenses are all payroll related.  This payroll request covers from April 1st through April 15th. recipient_justification: This request represents a draw of Year 2 funds under the prior grant 90YE0291 “Evaluation of Michigan’s Provider-Driven QRIS” which were re-obligated to this award representing expenditures since June 1, 2024. Data collection activities were robust including parent and provider interviews, provider survey, and partner reflection interviews, and all related analyses. We also conducted many secondary data analyses using both the QRIS and MiRegistry databases and gathered additional program data (i.e. observations and assessments) that will be used in upcoming analyses. Both primary and secondary data analyses were featured in our Year 2 annual report that was completed in this time period (November 2024). Preliminary analyses were shared at the annual conference in mid-June 2024. Costs to complete these tasks included labor, travel for presentations, supplies, third-party vendors for data assistance, as well as transcription services and compensation for participants’ time and efforts.

award_description: HEAD START AND EARLY HEAD START
recipient_justification: The Carole Robertson Center divides the request of funds to cover payrolls into two parts.  The first part is an estimated calculation of 80% of the previous payroll total charged to CH-HS, this is our estimated request.  After the current payroll payment is completed the total amount paid plus benefits and Indirect Cost is calculated; from this total the previously requested amount (estimated) is subtracted, and the remaining difference is requested, this is what we call a complement.  In this case the Center has to pay salaries for the period 04/27/2025 to 05/10/2025 on 05/16/2025, we are requesting estimated funds in advance to cover the payroll charged to CH-HS.  The total amount charged to CH-HS of our  previous payroll 04/13/2025 to 04/26/2025 was $182,955.04, we calculated the 80% of this amount for the payroll 04/27/2025-05/10/2025 which is $146,364.03 plus $37,144.15 of Fringe Benefits and salary taxes, plus $18,350.82 of Indirect Cost.  182,955.04 x 80% = 146,364.03 + 37,144.15 = 183,508.18 + 18,350.82 (10% for Indirect Cost)  = $201,859.00 which is the estimated amount we are requesting.
agency_lead_justification: The expenses appear to be reasonable and generally allowable for the provision of Head Start services to promote the school readiness of children from low-income families, birth to five, by fostering their cognitive, social, and emotional development through comprehensive services in early learning, health, and family well-being.

recipient_justification:
This payment request is necessary to cover operating expenses for the Kids In Crisis (KIC) 10-bed shelter program for children between the ages of 12 and 17 during the period of May 1, 2025 – May 31, 2025. The funds are reimbursing eligible costs incurred for essential services including:
•	Personnel and Fringe (Budget Categories: Personnel, Fringe): Salaries, FICA, SUI costs and health benefits for full-time staff providing daily supervision, case management, health care, educational services, and administration at the 10-bed shelter.
•	Supplies and Food (Budget Category: Supplies): Daily meals, hygiene kits, school supplies, and household items necessary to support up to 10 children at a time.
•	Contracted Services (Budget Category: Contractual): Medical care provided by licensed professionals, janitorial services, HR support services.
•	Other Program Costs (Budget Category: Other): Utilities, minor repairs, transportation of children for appointments and school attendance, software maintenance, and required background checks and training.
The shelter operates 24/7, year-round, and is staffed accordingly to ensure the safety and well-being of children in our care. All expenses are necessary to maintain state-licensed operations and meet strict requirements for the care and timely return of children to family. Costs are consistent with our approved budget and reflect reasonable and appropriate use of federal funds to ensure continuity of services without interruption.
agency_lead_justification: The expenses described are consistent with the purpose of the Kids In Crisis program and are generally reasonable for this program.

recipient_justification: Purpose of the Funds Request This justification outlines the need for requesting funds from the Payment Management System (PMS) to cover allowable expenditures for five grants under the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (DHHS) Office of Head Start. The funds requested are necessary to maintain continuous operations and services that directly support the delivery of high-quality early childhood education and family services. Specifically, the requested funds will cover multiple categories of expenditures, including payroll, employee health benefits, facility operations, transportation, professional services, and programmatic support costs incurred or anticipated for the periods ending April 30, 2025, and May 1, 2025. These costs are consistent with the approved budgets for each grant and are essential for uninterrupted service delivery to enrolled children, families, and program staff.
