recipient_justification: VT FVPSA FORMULA GRANTS Q3-Jan-Mar 2025- The FVPSA formula grant in Vermont provides essential services to crime victims and their children who are facing extremely traumatic and dangerous situations involving domestic and family violence. Twelve Vermont Network programs receive subgrants in FVPSA.  In this federal draw, 91.2% of the funding is to support the salaries and benefits of the professionals who provide support and shelter,  24/7 for Vermont citizens, in crisis;  4.3 % was used for goods and services, .45% for outreach to inform communities about services; 1.5% for hotline personnel, 2% for other expenses, such as one program using de minimis and another prorating funding towards an audit.  The Vermont Center for Crime Victim Services utilizes a grants management system that requires that all subgrants are approved and will prevent a subgrantee from spending outside of a preapproved budget category by more than 10% of the line item when submitting their quarterly financial re
agency_lead_justification: Expenses appear to be reasonable and generally allowable per FVPSA statute 42 U.S.C. § 10401 et seq.

recipient_justification: The requested funds are essential to the ongoing delivery of high-quality early childhood education services in alignment with the Head Start Program Performance Standards. These expenditures are directly tied to the objectives and budget categories outlined in our approved Head Start grant application. Examples of allowable and necessary purchases included in this request for reimbursement include payroll to support instructional staff, copy paper and printer ink for classroom and administrative use, recruitment materials such as branded swag, student journals for literacy development, and reading bikes to enhance classroom libraries. recipient_justification:
Time period covers April 13, 2025 to April 26, 2025. Payroll and fringe benefits encompass the total compensation provided to employees. Payroll includes salaries and wages. Fringe benefits refer to employer payroll tax obligations like Social Security, Medicare, unemployment insurance, and workers’ compensation. Also, fringe benefits refer to non-wage compensations such as employer-paid health, dental, and vision insurance, retirement plan contributions, life and disability insurance, and paid leave including vacation and sick days. Supplies refer to consumable items necessary for day-to-day operations and program delivery. This includes general office supplies and minor equipment, as well as program-specific materials such as educational tools for classroom settings.
Training and Technical Assistance (T&TA) supports the development and enhancement of staff competencies and organizational effectiveness.

award_description: HEAD START AND EARLY HEAD START
recipient_justification:
Award 04CH01276501 was awarded to provide Head Start and Early Head Start Services to families in Baldwin, Clarke, and Escambia Counties in Alabama. The requested funds are to reimburse expenses for staff salary and fringe benefits, education and classroom supplies, diapering supplies, administrative costs, and occupancy expenses (rent & utilities). 
Justification for Funds:
Educational Resources and Supplies:
Funds were used to purchase necessary educational materials and resources to facilitate the learning and development of children enrolled in the program. This includes age-appropriate books, teaching aids, and classroom supplies to ensure a high-quality, engaging learning environment.
Personnel Costs:
A portion of the requested funds are allocated to compensating qualified staff, including teachers, educational assistants, and support personnel. These funds will also help provide staff training and professional development, ensuring they are equipped with the latest methodologies in early childhood education.
Administrative Costs:
Funds also support administrative costs associated with managing and overseeing the program’s activities, including data tracking, compliance with federal and state regulations, and reporting requirements to ensure proper utilization of resources. The funds requested are to support the continued development and implementation of the the Head Start program, aimed at providing comprehensive early childhood education, health, and family services to low-income children and families. This request is essential to ensure the program’s effectiveness, sustainability, and the overall success of our service delivery for the upcoming program period.
agency_lead_justification: The expenses described are generally reasonable and consistent with the purpose of the Head Start Grant program.

recipient_justification: This payment request is for the Early Head Start Operating Grant awarded by the Administration for Children and Families, Division of Early Childhood Development, to WCCA, Inc.  for the grant period 8/01/2024 - 7/31/2025 Grant Award Number 04HP00057601. This grant is intended to support the provision of comprehensive Early Head Start services to eligible preschool children and their families in Henderson, Transylvania, Rutherford and Polk Counties, in accordance with the Head Start Act and applicable regulations. This payment request seeks reimbursement for the balance of expenses incurred during the month of April 2025. These expenses, including personnel salaries and wages, fringe benefits, rents, contractual payments and other operating costs, are essential for the continued operation of our Head Start program and directly support the delivery of comprehensive services to the children and families of Western North Carolina. The key categories of expenditures included in this reimbursement request are as follows: personnel expenses and allocated fringe benefits; classroom supplies; monthly allocation of facilities and IT support; monthly contractual cost such as utilities, communications and cleaning cost. These expenditures were directly incurred in the month of April to maintain daily operations of our Early Head Start program.

recipient_justification: Of the $178,000 requested, $84,477 was for the bi-weekly payroll and the $93,523 was for the Annual Property insurance payment.  The payroll request is for the reimbursement for Head Start Childcare staff salaries, health insurance, taxes, & 401K.  This payroll is for the pay-period 03-30-25 to 4-12/25.  These staff provide supervision and care for children who have been determined to be income eligible for the Early Head Start Program.  They provide daily instruction for pre-school age children that are 3 and 4 that follows the local ISD school calendar and schedule. Additional program staff such as Center Directors, Education Specialists, nutritional staff, and the program director are paid for their hours worked during this time period on this payroll.  The mission of the HS program is to promote the school readiness of young children from low-income families by enhancing their cognitive, social, and emotional development.  These staff are tasked with that mission.  The annual insurance payment covers the Property, Liability, Vehicle, and umbrella insurance to ensure that assets purchased with Federal funds are properly insured.  The Program operates in 12 centers across a highly rural portion of Texas and owns several vehicles that are used for staff to travel to and from each location.  The vehicle insurance includes 5 small school buses that can be used to transport children to and from school $30,948, Property and Liability Insurance for 12 childcare centers $55,588, and Umbrella policy $6,988.  The insurance cost is cost allocated with other programs when appropriate.
agency_lead_justification: The expenses described are generally reasonable and consistent with the purpose of the Head Start Grant program.

recipient_justification: Total draw -$173,300.61. Breakdown as follows: $143,192.50 for payments to outside providers for childcare subsidy assistance on behalf of clients attending these centers. This is important because it supports eligible clients with childcare and ensures access. $9,692.46 is for tribally operated supplies to include necessary items for program functions such as office supplies, key and screen replacement, printing services, hearing machine diagnostics, cleaning supplies, therapy supplies, kitchen supplies and more. All these purchases align with CCDF to ensure operations of our tribally operated center, to meet expectations for health and safety and quality services. $12,111.28 is for quality assurances of program. These purchases included food, classroom supplies and food vendor payments for staff meetings. These purchases align with our CCDF plan to ensure access to quality services. $4,420.00 is to cover education costs to align with staff professional development plans. This aligns with infant/toddler quality assurances as it is going to provide access to more providers for infants and toddlers at our tribally operated center. $3,884.37 is to cover costs associated with sending two leaders from our tribal lead agency to attend the CCDF 2026-20228 plan training. The staff members who attended this training collaborated of writing the CCDF plan and our program benefits from them receiving the training to prepare for the new grant cycle.

recipient_justification: This is a payment request of incentive funds from the 2011 Child Support grant.  This amount is the balance of incentive funds in the 2011 grant,and our state has been encouraged to request the remainder of these funds by the Administration for Children and Families of the US Department of Health and Human Services.  States earn incentive funds from the federal government based on their performance on five performance measures.  These funds are required to be reinvested into the Child Support program.  The Child Support program is a joint federal, state, and local effort to secure financial support from noncustodial parents.  These incentives are designed to incentivize states to collect more child support, establish more paternity and support orders, and improve their overall performance.

award_description: HEAD START AND EARLY HEAD START
recipient_justification:
This draw request includes payment for a diverse range of expenses that are essential to the effective operation of our Early Head Start and Head Start programs. These costs are aligned with applicable Head Start Program Performance Standards (HSPPS) and are necessary to maintain compliance and quality service delivery.

Included in this request are:

Cleaning supplies and janitorial services, which are critical to maintaining a safe and sanitary learning environment in accordance with HSPPS 1302.47(b)(1)(i) and 1302.47(b)(2)(i).

Playground resurfacing, required to ensure safe outdoor learning and play environments, supporting HSPPS 1302.31(e)(4) and 1302.47(b)(2)(iv).

New facility signage for recently acquired sites, facilitating community awareness and accessibility, in compliance with HSPPS 1302.13.

Routine operational expenses including utility bills, rent payments, and per diem allowances for staff participating in professional development trainings and other program-related travel.

All expenditures are consistent with the approved budget and are necessary, reasonable, and allocable to the Head Start program.
agency_lead_justification: The expenses appear to be reasonable and generally allowable for the provision of Head Start services to promote the school readiness of children from low-income families, birth to five, by fostering their cognitive, social, and emotional development through comprehensive services in early learning, health, and family well-being.

award_description: HEAD START AND EARLY HEAD START
recipient_justification:
The expenses requested for reimbursement are directly aligned with the operation of our Head Start and Early Head Start programs and support the delivery of comprehensive services to enrolled children and families. Specifically, the expenses include:
. Wages and benefits for our staff.
• Utilities (electricity, water, gas) necessary to operate program facilities where children receive educational and support services..
• Food and non-food supplies (e.g., ingredients, serving items, cleaning supplies) used in the preparation and delivery of meals that meet the USDA Child Nutrition guidelines for enrolled children.
• Vehicle fuel and repair/maintenance costs for buses and agency vehicles used to transport children and for staff travel to centers, training sessions, and home visits.
• Contracted IT services to support technology infrastructure necessary for program operations, including child assessments, attendance tracking, and staff communication.
• Literacy supplies (such as books and reading materials) for children to support their language and literacy development as required by the Head Start Early Learning Outcomes Framework.
• Staff training costs to ensure compliance with Head Start Program Performance Standards and to maintain a well-qualified workforce.

These expenditures are essential to the ongoing implementation and operation of the Head Start and Early Head Start programs and are consistent with the purposes of the grant award.
agency_lead_justification: The expense(s) described are generally reasonable and consistent with the purpose of the Head Start Grant program.

recipient_justification:
This drawdown request is for Allies' Early Head Start (EHS) program's operational expenses incurred during the period of January 2025. The funds will be used to cover essential program expenses directly tied to the provision of services to children and families, in line with the goals of the EHS program and the objectives outlined in the grant award.

Specifically, the requested funds will be allocated to the following areas:

Staffing Costs: Salaries for direct service staff, including educators, home visitors, and program coordinators, who deliver daily services to enrolled children and their families. These services include early childhood education, health screenings, and parent engagement activities.

Educational Materials: Purchase of developmentally appropriate materials, books, and educational resources to support the curriculum and activities designed to meet the developmental needs of children in the program.

Health and Nutrition Services: Funds will cover expenses for health screenings, nutritional assessments, and direct support for families in meeting the health and well-being needs of children, including vision, hearing, and developmental screenings.

Parent and Family Engagement Activities: The allocation will also support family engagement services, including workshops, family events, and other activities designed to enhance parent involvement in the education and development of their children.

The requested amount aligns with the approved budget for this period and is necessary to ensure continued service delivery to the children and families served by the Early Head Start program. All expenses are in full compliance with the EHS program's guidelines and requirements, as well as the terms outlined in the grant award.

This request has been reviewed for accuracy and is fully in compliance with the Executive Order 14222, as well as the objectives and allowable costs as defined by the EHS funding regulations.
agency_lead_justification: The expenses described are generally reasonable and consistent with the purpose of the Preschool Development Grant program.

award_description: HEAD START AND EARLY HEAD START
recipient_justification: Request to reimburse EEC/Head Start for balance of total expense incurred in February by Head Start.  The previous Finance Director's system for determining requests was not determined. I am the new CFO for Head Start and am creating a consistent method of requests, as follows. Previous method - not determined. Current Method - on/around mid-month a revenue/expense report will be generated showing all current expense incurred by Head Start program for previous month. A request for payment will then be submitted. One week later, after previous month has been finalized/closed, a request for payment will be submitted for amount of balance (much smaller) of remaining expenses from previous month. Note - I joined this organization in February, and when analyzing expense reports, it appears the funding previously requested for February did not match total February expense/revenue. MIP support document Feb provided.
agency_lead_justification: The expenses described are generally reasonable and consistent with the purpose of the Head Start Grant program.

recipient_justification: VT FVPSA M GRANTS Q3-Jan-Mar 2025- 97% of this federal draw was distributed to ten programs to cover the personnel and benefits line items for workforce retention and hiring resulting from paradigm shifts in the US workforce post-pandemic and 4% was used for good and services. Expenses are allowable under federal guidance. In a US Department of Commerce 2024 study, “Understanding America’s Labor Shortage,” Vermont was classified to have the most severe labor shortage, with only 36 workers available for every 100 jobs. Recruitment difficulties are even harder for domestic and sexual violence programs where advocates are paid an average of only $23.61 an hour (barely a living wage), to provide 24/7 assistance, and provide life-saving shelter, safety planning, and services for crime victims in crisis. Also, many victims waited until after the pandemic was over to report their crimes, increasing the need for services, causing a surge in post-pandemic cases.
agency_lead_justification: Expenses appear to be reasonable and generally allowable per FVPSA statute 42 U.S.C. § 10401 et seq.

During the period 3/1/25-3/31/25, subrecipient activities included: Held the kick-off meeting for Cohort 2 of the IRP Fellowship activity; Closed the application for the Educator Advisory Board - received 88 applicants w/ 62 meeting minimum requirements; The New Mexico Action Research Partnership with the State of New Mexico ECDC launched the higher education survey which will inform NM’s aligned career pathway. recipient_justification:
To whom it may concern:
On April 25, a funding request in the amount of $166,455.00 was submitted to PMS, broken down as follows:
02CH012087-04 $ 27,000.00
02CH012088-04 $  33,000.00
02ND000075	  $ 5,000.00
02TD000136-01 $153,824.00
Today, we received a communication from HHS requesting additional information: “Additional clarification required for your recent payment request from PMS.”
The grant under subaccount 02TD00013601 was awarded for the construction of the Paraiso de Amor center. The NOA relevant remark is transcribed below.

26. REMARKS

This grant action awards Hurricane Relief funds in the amount of $1,969,449 for the 7/01/2020-06/30/2022 budget period. Funds under CAN G020700 are designated to support the restoration of Head Start and/or Early Head Start services following Hurricanes Harvey, Irma, and Maria in accordance with Office of Head Start (OHS) Program Instruction ACF-PI-HS-18-02 (the Program Instruction).
These funds are awarded following review of a funding request (application) demonstrating that the funds awarded fall within one or more of the six categories identified in the Program Instruction and are for necessary expenses directly related to the consequences of Hurricanes Harvey, Irma, and/or Maria in areas served by Fundacion para el Hogar Propio, Inc.
CONSTRUCTION: $1,969,449
Proposed improvements to the Paraíso de Amor EHS center for the following:
•	$34,046- Engineering, geotechnical, structural, land surveying, environmental, and permits.
•	$164,514- Design Services
•	$10,000- Legal Services
•	$1,545,981-Major Renovation Costs:
- The FDHP expects to serve the assigned enrollment of twenty (20) infants and toddlers in three (3) Early Head Start environments at the renovated facility. However, it will have available space for twenty-four (24) children. This would require a redistribution of the spaces in the existing structure, and partial demolition of existing walls. The structure in whole won’t be demolished. The new design solution will allow the entrance relocation of the facility from the front (street facing) to a protected area on the left side of the building (side façade). - The front façade will be covered with vegetation to soften the urban “hardness” of the immediate context. The site accommodates six parking spaces inside the center’s facilities and 15 parking spaces in its perimeter.
- The outdoor natural playground will be located on the back patio of the existing building.
26. REMARKS (Continued from previous page)

This action extends the budget and project period to January 31, 2025, for the completion of approved activities in the amount of $1,607,565 for Paraiso de Amor Center at Las Piedras, Puerto Rico.
Funds must not be expended for any other purpose(s).
The construction is nearing completion; therefore, the fund request is intended for the payment of Certification #13.
If you need any additional information, please do not hesitate to contact us.

award_description: HRA BRISTOL HEAD START AND EARLY HEAD START PROGRAM
recipient_justification: This drawdown request $152,598.60 is for the reimbursement of allowable, approved expenditures related to the delivery of Head Start services during the period 04/15/2025 – 04/25/2025. These expenses have been processed or will be within 72 hours of receipt of funds as per the federal drawdown requirements. Expenses include costs in the following approved budget categories: Personnel (teaching and support staff payroll), Fringe Benefits (health and retirement), and Supplies (classroom materials and sanitation items). These expenditures align with the program’s approved budget and directly support classroom instruction, program operations, and administrative oversight as outlined in our grant agreement. Funds will sustain services across three center-based classrooms, support compliance monitoring, and ensure uninterrupted delivery of high-quality early childhood education.

recipient_justification: Thank you for your inquiry.  We are requesting $149,995 to purchase five SUV passenger vehicles to replace our small fleet of aging & unsafe vehicles that have been used by our Head Start program since 2009.  These five vehicles will be used to transport prepared meals, food & materials across our five Head Start centers located throughout rural Columbia County, NY. In addition we will transport enrolled children and their parents to required health and human services appointments as needed.  Program Managers and other staff will drive these vehicles to our five centers to support and supervise the teaching teams in delivering high quality Head Start Services to enrolled children and families.  With the guidance of our assigned Office of Head Start staff we followed the existing policies and procedures in developing this request.  We received approval to modify our budget using already allocated funds, and have also received permission to liquidate these approved funds.  We have an approved vendor ready to immediately deliver these vehicles that meet our specifications at a reasonable cost.

recipient_justification: To provide support services at temporary domestic violence shelters that will afford survivors the opportunity to break the cycle of violence in their lives. Provides crisis response and comprehensive case management to victims of all forms of human trafficking up to age 21 using a trauma-informed approach to promote victim safety and well-being.  Information, psychoeducation, and guidance is also provided to parents, guardians, and caregivers to strengthen their relationship with the victims and to increase their ability to provide appropriate supervision and support. Statewide services include Ohana Conferencing, Youth Circles, Family Finding/Family Connections, and Project First Care provided to Child Welfare Services, Voluntary Case Management, and Family Strengthening Services families, youth currently in care, and youth/young adults formerly in care up to age 26.

award_description: GY2024 REFUGEE SUPPORT SERVICES AND SET ASIDES
recipient_justification: This award is for the Refugee Support Services (RSS) program, funded by the Office of Refugee Resettlement (ORR). RSS is used primarily for services designed to enable ORR-eligible populations to obtain jobs within one year of enrolling in services to achieve economic self-sufficiency as soon as possible. RSS also addresses barriers to employment, such as social adjustment, interpretation, and translation. This drawdown is for the continuation of the RSS program in April and May for New Jersey. These funds cover IRC’s RSS administrative expenses, including salaries, fringe, and associated operational costs such as facilities and equipment, and payments for RSS administrative expenses to IRC’s ten sub-awardees in New Jersey for their RSS implementation during this period.
agency_lead_justification: The expenses described are consistent with the purpose of the RSS program. The expenses as described are generally reasonable for this program.

recipient_justification:
The facility that is utilized is located at 2330 TX-1604 Loop, San Antonio, TX. The request for funding reimbursement is to pay the rent for the month of May 2025, which Compass Connections has already funded to the lessor as required by the contracted lease. On a daily basis, the unaccompanied children are transported to this location from 7:30am-5:00pm where they receive educational instruction, meals, case management, legal services, and all other required services. Compass Connections also utilizes this space to provide training for the foster parents and staff associated with this program. This facility also is staffed 24 hours a day, year-round to intake any children that are mandated to care as they are located. Case management works with licensed foster care facilities to place these children in safe facilities. All of these requirements are a part of the agreement with US Department of Health and Human Services. This budget line category is OTHER.
Also, a part of this funding request were funds for the payment of bona fide benefits (health, dental, vision) as mandated by the U.S. Department of Labor under the McNamara-O'Hara Service Contract Act (SCA) for the staff that is providing the services to the unaccompanied children as previously described. The benefits coverage that is being requested is also for the period of May 2025, and is dictated by SCA Wage Determination 2015-5253 for all employees that the US Department of HHS has agreed under terms of this agreement. This budget line category is FRINGE.
agency_lead_justification: The expenses described are consistent with the purpose of the COMPASS CONNECTIONS program. The expenses as described are generally reasonable for this program.

recipient_justification:
This 90ZU054903 payment request is for our Mi Futuro Shelter program under the Federal Award Project Title of Residential (Shelter and/or Transitional Foster Care) Services for Unaccompanied Children-Licensed and the budget period of 4/1/25-3/31/26. The payment request is for program operational expenditures to run our Mi Futuro Residential Shelter program and are within our approved budgeted object class categories of Personnel, Fringe Benefits, Supplies, Contractual, Other, and Indirect. The time period of expenditures is from the first half of April 2025. 

These operational expenditures are necessary in order to support the youth in our care and the day-to-day activities of the residential Mi Futuro Shelter program.  Expenses in this payment request are broken down into the following: the workforce staffing the program, associated workforce taxes and benefits, program supplies, contracted services (interpretation and translation of less common languages and dialects), other (building and utility expenses, information technology infrastructure, client support expenses such as food and clothing, staff training), and indirect costs. 

The object class category summaries for this payment request are as follows:

Total Personnel 105,282.33
Total Fringe Benefit 30,690.39
Total Supplies 227.15

Total Indirect Expenses 0.00
Total Allowable Expenses 138,815.06
Total Unallowable Expenses 0.00

All expenses included in this payment request have been liquidated and there are no unliquidated obligations to remove.

recipient_justification:
Award 04CH011305 was awarded to provide Early Head Start services to families in Mobile County, Alabama. The requested funds are to reimburse expenses for staff salary and fringe benefits, education and classroom supplies, diapering supplies, administrative costs, and occupancy expenses (rent & utilities). 
Justification for Funds:
Educational Resources and Supplies:
Funds were used to purchase necessary educational materials and resources to facilitate the learning and development of children enrolled in the program. This includes age-appropriate books, teaching aids, and classroom supplies to ensure a high-quality, engaging learning environment.
Personnel Costs:
A portion of the requested funds are allocated to compensating qualified staff, including teachers, educational assistants, and support personnel. These funds will also help provide staff training and professional development, ensuring they are equipped with the latest methodologies in early childhood education.
Administrative Costs:
Funds also support administrative costs associated with managing and overseeing the program’s activities, including data tracking, compliance with federal and state regulations, and reporting requirements to ensure proper utilization of resources. 
The funds requested are to support the continued development and implementation of the the Head Start program, aimed at providing comprehensive early childhood education, health, and family services to low-income children and families. This request is essential to ensure the program’s effectiveness, sustainability, and the overall success of our service delivery for the upcoming program period.
agency_lead_justification: The expenses described are generally reasonable and consistent with the purpose of the Head Start Grant program.

award_description: HEAD START AND EARLY HEAD START
recipient_justification:
Gulf Regional Early Childhood Services seeks the disbursement of funds through the Payment Management System (PMS) to support the ongoing operations of our Early Head Start and Head Start programs, serving families in Baldwin, Clarke, and Escambia Counties in Alabama. The requested funds are essential for covering allowable and allocable expenses, for the previous two weeks including:
•	Personnel Costs: Salaries and benefits for teaching and support staff, in compliance with 45 CFR §75.430, ensuring that compensation aligns with the approved budget and is necessary for program delivery. ($100,503)
•	Facility Expenses: Payments for allocated rent under operating leases and other occupancy costs (i.e. utilities, janitorial services, etc.) to maintain safe and conducive learning environments, as permitted by 45 CFR §1303.44 and §1303.45. ($21,740)
•	Program Supplies: Acquisition of educational materials and resources that directly contribute to the program's objectives of enhancing school readiness. ($2,575)
•	Administrative/Indirect Cost: The allowable de minimis rate covers a portion of the administrative costs to support the infrastructure and general administration that allow us to meet program objectives. ($12,482)
agency_lead_justification: The expenses appear to be reasonable and generally allowable for the provision of Head Start services to promote the school readiness of children from low-income families, birth to five, by fostering their cognitive, social, and emotional development through comprehensive services in early learning, health, and family well-being.

recipient_justification: This program (CIP) is critical to the courts & legal community in their efforts to provide safety, permanency & well-being for child victims involved in foster care. CIP staff observe hearings, review files & conduct interviews to audit compliance with law. They provide orientation and advance training for judges and implement plans to improve effectiveness & efficiency. They introduce prevention models designed to safely keep child victims out of foster care and enhance the effectiveness of treatment court and birth to three program. They open access to data showing system needs & effectiveness of improvement efforts. Staff work with a task force to implement and update the strategic plan. CIP funding provides for legal community training and the supplies to support audit and training efforts. Technical support for audit software and multi-system youth efforts is paid for with these funds.
agency_lead_justification: The expenses described appear consistent with the purpose of the State Court Improvement Program.

recipient_justification: The requested draw for 90ZU0633-01-00 Residential (Staff Secure) Services for Unacommpanied Children requesting reimbursement for funds expended during the Period of 07-01-24 to 03-31-25 not reimbursed in prior payments. recipient_justification:
This 90ZU061602 payment request is for our Long Term Group Home program with a budget period of 1/1/25-12/31/25; the payment request is for program operational expenditures to run our Long Term Group Home program and are within our approved budgeted object class categories of Personnel, Fringe Benefits, Supplies, Contractual, Other, and Indirect. The time period of expenditures is predominantly from the second half of April 2025 and does not include any Unliquidated Obligations; prior Unliquidated Obligations from the budget period of 1/1/25-12/31/25 that have since been paid, are now included.

These operational expenditures are necessary in order to support the youth in our care and the day-to-day activities of the residential Long Term Group Home program.  Expenses in this payment request are broken down into the following: the workforce staffing the program, associated workforce taxes and benefits, program supplies, contracted services (interpretation and translation of less common languages and dialects), other (building and utility expenses, information technology infrastructure, client support expenses such as food and clothing, staff training), and indirect costs. 

All current unliquidated obligations have been removed from the totals and the payment request for those expenditures will happen in subsequent periods once Morrison Child and Family Services has made payment.
agency_lead_justification: The expenses described are consistent with the purpose of the Morrison Child & Family Services program. The expenses as described are generally reasonable for this program.

recipient_justification:
This payment request is submitted to draw down supplemental one-time funds awarded for critical facility upgrades to the SECU Hope Center, an Early Head Start service location. The use of these funds is necessary to enhance the physical safety, accessibility, and overall environment of the facility to ensure a secure and developmentally appropriate setting for infants, toddlers, and their families.
The funds will be used for the following specific purposes:
•	$45,356 – Landscaping: Landscaping will address current safety hazards such as uneven terrain and poorly maintained grounds, while also creating a welcoming and developmentally appropriate outdoor environment for learning and family engagement activities. Improvements will support positive sensory experiences and meet Head Start Program Performance Standards for safe and healthy learning environments.
•	$85,996.68 – Purchase and Installation of a Security System: A comprehensive security system is necessary to safeguard the facility's children, families, and staff. The system will include surveillance cameras, access controls, and alarm systems to monitor the premises' entrances, exits, and activity. This aligns with Early Head Start’s commitment to child safety and protection, particularly considering increasing concerns around school and childcare facility security nationwide.
These facility enhancements are directly aligned with the purpose of the supplemental funds and the overall mission of the Early Head Start program—to provide a safe, nurturing, and developmentally supportive environment for low-income families with infants and toddlers. By investing in secure and well-maintained infrastructure, this project supports the long-term sustainability and quality of Early Head Start services at the SECU Hope Center.
agency_lead_justification: The expenses appear to be reasonable and generally allowable for the provision of Head Start services to promote the school readiness of children from low-income families, birth to five, by fostering their cognitive, social, and emotional development through comprehensive services in early learning, health, and family well-being.

recipient_justification: Of the $130,400 requested, 83,654 was for the bi-weekly payroll and the $46,746 was for the Annual Property insurance payment.  The payroll request is for the reimbursement for Early Head Start Childcare staff salaries, health insurance, taxes, & 401K.  This payroll is for the pay-period 03-30-25 to 4-12/25.  These staff provide supervision and care for children who have been determined to be income eligible for the Early Head Start Program.  They provide childcare from the hours of 7:30 am to 3:30 pm.  Additional program staff such as Center Directors, Education Specialists, nutritional staff, and the program director are paid for their hours worked during this time period on this payroll.  The mission of the EHS program is to support the development of infants and toddlers to promote their future success in school and life while also supporting parents and families in achieving their own goals.  These staff are tasked with that mission.  The annual insurance payment covers the Property, Liability, Vehicle, and umbrella insurance to ensure that assets purchased with Federal funds are properly insured.  The Program operates in 12 centers across a highly rural portion of Texas and owns several vehicles that are used for staff to travel to and from each location.  $7500 was for vehicle insurance, $35,794 was for property & liability, and $3492 was for Umbrella coverage.
agency_lead_justification: The expenses described are generally reasonable and consistent with the purpose of the Head Start Grant program.

recipient_justification:
Anthem Strong Families (“ASF”) is seeking reimbursement for funds expended according to the financial reimbursement records as submitted to the Office of Grants Management (“OGM”) on Friday, April 11, 2025, as mandated by our Subaccount documentation.
The reimbursement is for Administration for Children and Families, FRAMEWorks subgrant funds that were expended to carry out the requirements of the program for this grant for the month of March 2025.   As we cannot attach a copy (.pdf or Word), of the documentation within this justification box, a description of the FRAMEWorks subgrant reimbursement package is as follows:
A.	Cover letter to OGM from ASF’s CEO requesting reimbursement of funds in the amount of $130,017.45 with documentation of:
a.	NFE Attestation
b.	General Ledger Detail Report
c.	Month to Date Budget vs. Actuals
d.	Completed SF-270, and
e.	Supporting Financial Documents (Budget Expense Summary Template, Approved Budget, Statement of Activity by Class)
B.	Non-Federal Entity Attestation – Certifying that we have received, understand, and certify that ASF is operating within the parameters of its grant/cooperative agreement(s)
C.	Request for Advance or Reimbursement – Detail and certification of program outlays for the March, 2025
D.	Expenditure Summary Detail allocable by Direct Charges and Indirect Charges, reflecting the total amounts by month
E.	ASF March, 2025, Statement of Activity by Class (Income Statement)
F.	ASF March, 2025, Budget vs. Actuals (Comparative Income Statement)
G.	Original Notice of Award for Award #90ZB0027-05-01
H.	ASF General Ledger – Detailing expenditures for the month of March, 2025.

recipient_justification:
Early Head Start Economic Improvement Council, Inc.
Time period covers April 13, 2025 to April 26, 2025. Payroll and fringe benefits encompass the total compensation provided to employees. Payroll includes salaries and wages. Fringe benefits refer to employer payroll tax obligations like Social Security, Medicare, unemployment insurance, and workers’ compensation. Also, fringe benefits refer to non-wage compensations such as employer-paid health, dental, and vision insurance, retirement plan contributions, life and disability insurance, and paid leave including vacation and sick days. Supplies refer to consumable items necessary for day-to-day operations and program delivery. This includes general office supplies and minor equipment, as well as program-specific materials such as educational tools for classroom settings.
Training and Technical Assistance (T&TA) supports the development and enhancement of staff competencies and organizational effectiveness.

award_description: ENHANCEMENT OF THE MEDLAW PARTNERSHIP OF WESTERN NEW YORK THROUGH CENTER FOR ELDER LAW & JUSTICE.
recipient_justification: The payment request is for services rendered by Center for Elder Law & Justice under the Medical Legal Partnership program from 1/1/2025 – 3/31/2025 in accordance with the executed cooperative agreement. The program delivers direct legal services to patients; helping navigate legal issues that can negatively impact their health and well-being. The cost incurred for the delivery of services include time spent by staff positions in accordance with the approved budget in the Notice of Award (Personnel Costs, Supplies and Other). Staffing includes 2.0 FTE navigators to address patient issues that are a barrier to discharge, reducing unnecessary utilization of our healthcare system; 2.9 FTE attorneys to provide legal counseling, case management and representation, also decreasing length of stay and unnecessary readmissions. All personnel charged to the grant worked directly on patient-facing activities.
agency_lead_justification: The expenses described are consistent with the purpose of the program. The expenses as described are generally reasonable for this program.

recipient_justification:
Service Date: March 1, 2025 – March 31, 2025. Total benefits expenditure: $28,021.00. 
The Hawai’i Home Energy Assistance Program(H-HEAP) provides utility payment assistance to households who are low income and considered vulnerable.  This program is referred to as the Low-Income Energy Assistance Program on a national level (LIHEAP).  Vulnerable households include the elderly, disabled and those with minor children. These H-HEAP Energy Crisis Intervention payments are utility assistance payments which restore a disconnected energy service or prevent disconnection of services for households currently at risk.

Service Date 01/31/2025. Total administrative expenditures: $82,595.00. The Hawai’i Home Energy Assistance Program(H-HEAP) provides utility payment assistance to households who are low income and considered vulnerable.  This program is referred to as the Low-Income Energy Assistance Program on a national level (LIHEAP).  Vulnerable households include the elderly, disabled and those with minor children. These H-HEAP Community Action Agencies are contracted to complete intake and processing of applications for the program.  This assistance program enables the community to meet basic shelter and day to day needs.
agency_lead_justification: The expenses described are consistent with the purpose of the LIHEAP program. The expenses as described are generally reasonable for this program.

recipient_justification: Reimbursement of Spent Funds. The Title IV-E Foster Care program helps states, Indian tribes, tribal organizations and tribal consortia (tribes) to provide safe and stable out-of-home care for children under the jurisdiction of the state or tribal child welfare agency until the children are returned home safely, placed with adoptive families, or placed in other planned arrangements for permanency. The program provides funds to assist with the costs of foster care maintenance for eligible children; administrative costs to manage the program; and training for public agency staff, foster parents and eligible professional partner agency staff. In addition, $3 million is reserved for technical assistance and plan development/implementation awards to eligible tribes.
agency_lead_justification: The title IV-E is operated under an approved title IV-E plan.  Additional supporting documentation of the expenditures are coordinated by the submission of the CB-496 form.

recipient_justification:
Anthem Strong Families (“ASF”) is seeking reimbursement for funds expended according to the financial reimbursement records as submitted to the Office of Grants Management (“OGM”) on Friday, April 11, 2025, as mandated by our Subaccount documentation.
The reimbursement is for Administration for Children and Families, FIRE subgrant funds that were expended to carry out the requirements of the program for this grant for the month of March 2025.   As we cannot attach a copy (.pdf or Word), of the documentation within this justification box, a description of the FIRE subgrant reimbursement package is as follows:
A.	Cover letter to OGM from ASF’s CEO requesting reimbursement of funds in the amount of $121,001.19 with documentation of:
a.	NFE Attestation
b.	General Ledger Detail Report
c.	Month to Date Budget vs. Actuals
d.	Completed SF-270, and
e.	Supporting Financial Documents (Budget Expense Summary Template, Approved Budget, Statement of Activity by Class)
B.	Non-Federal Entity Attestation – Certifying that we have received, understand, and certify that ASF is operating within the parameters of its grant/cooperative agreement(s)
C.	Request for Advance or Reimbursement – Detail and certification of program outlays for the March, 2025
D.	Expenditure Summary Detail allocable by Direct Charges and Indirect Charges, reflecting the total amounts by month
E.	ASF March, 2025, Statement of Activity by Class (Income Statement)
F.	ASF March, 2025, Budget vs. Actuals (Comparative Income Statement)
G.	Original Notice of Award for Award #90ZJ0006-05-01
H.	ASF General Ledger – Detailing expenditures for the month of March, 2025.

recipient_justification:
This request for payment is for a reimbursement of expenses incurred for our Agency’s Unaccompanied Children - Transitional Foster Care (UC TFC) program, Grant Number: 90ZU0414. Under the supervision of the Office of Refugee Resettlement (ORR) and Administration for Children and Families (ACF), our program was tasked with connecting Unaccompanied Alien children (UC) with vetted Sponsors (relatives, foster parents, etc.) who can take minors into their custody.

The expenses incurred were for the service period of April 1st to April 21st 2025. The expenses include personnel cost and daily operating expenses, all of which are in the approved budget line items.

Personnel costs include wages, fringe benefits, employer payroll taxes and workers’ compensation premium for our UC TFC program staff. The Village Family Services (TVFS) offers fringe benefits to employees. Benefit costs include Medical (PPO/HMO), Dental, Vision, life, short-term and long-term disability insurance premiums, and retirement plans employer match, from pay period 3/31/25 through 4/13/25. All wages and fringe benefit costs were necessary and reasonable for program operation and approved by ORR in the Personnel and Fringe Benefits budget categories.

Operating expenses include program staff mileage reimbursement for weekly client visits and whenever staff use their own personal vehicles to perform program duties. Staff are reimbursed at the current IRS approved mileage rate. Included are also the general liability and foster parent liability insurance expense allocated to the UC TFC program. As well as the monthly cost of the subscription to Binti’s online platform, to help manage UC TFC foster parents’ records. These costs have all been pre-approved in the “Other” budget class category under Grant Number 90ZU0414.
agency_lead_justification: The expenses described are consistent with the purpose of the VILLAGE FAMILY SERVICES, THE program. The expenses as described are generally reasonable for this program.

recipient_justification:
The reimbursement request for reference number 4040573038, under subaccount 05CH01248802, relates to the 5/8 check run for the Head Start grant. These funds are necessary for covering the following allowable expenses:

Payments to contracted Head Start partners, which ensure that direct services continue to be delivered to children and families.

Rent and utilities for Head Start centers, which are vital to maintaining safe and functional facilities for program operations.

Storage costs associated with storing program materials and equipment needed to support the Head Start program.

Maintenance expenses for the upkeep of Head Start centers, including necessary repairs and general facility care to ensure compliance with program standards.

These expenses are directly aligned with the goals and purpose of the Head Start program, ensuring continued program operation and service delivery. All costs are within the approved grant period and are necessary to meet the program’s operational needs.

recipient_justification: This draw request covers payroll expenses that are essential to the continued delivery of comprehensive services under our Early Head Start and Head Start grant. Specifically, the requested funds support compensation for instructional staff, family service workers, health and nutrition personnel, and program management—all of whom are directly responsible for implementing services required under the Head Start Program Performance Standards (HSPPS), including child development (1302.31), family engagement (1302.50), health and safety (1302.47), and program oversight (1302.101). These roles are critical to meeting staffing ratios, maintaining service continuity, and ensuring compliance with federal standards. The expenses are fully aligned with the approved budget and directly support the purposes of the grant.

recipient_justification: This is a payment request from the TANF grant for the reimbursement of expenditures incurred on the previous work day.  TANF (Temporary Assistance for Needy Families) provides funds to states to design and operate programs aimed at helping low-income families with children achieve economic security and stability, with a focus on promoting work and self-sufficiency.  The request is to reimburse expenditures paid for work activities (including case management), supportive services (including subgrantee payments for support services), fatherhood and two parent family formation and maintenance (including subgrantee payments for preventive services), child welfare services (including social worker provider), administration, and systems (including ADP operations and development).
agency_lead_justification:
The expenses listed above are consistent with those that are reasonable for accomplishing the statutory purposes of TANF and align with the following ACF-196R reporting line items: Line 7 (Work-Related Activities), Line 10 (Supportive Services), Line 11 (Two-Parent Family Formation and Maintenance), Line 16 (Child Welfare Services), Line 12 (Program Management), and Line 13 (Systems).

To ensure that TANF expenditures are not delayed, please clearly indicate the applicable ACF-196R line item for each expenditure category in future submissions. Providing this level of specificity is necessary for timely review and approval.

recipient_justification:
The funds associated with this request were spent on a number of activities.  These include, but are not limited to, 1) providing human trafficking prevention education to educators and other staff; 2) deliver human trafficking prevention education to students; 3) train qualified individuals employed to implement and replicate project activities throughout the school district and 4; providing human trafficking prevention education to caregivers.

Together, these activities will prepare educators and school staff to recognize and respond to students with high-risk profiles for human trafficking and recognize the signs, as well as building the skills of individual students to keep themselves safe.
agency_lead_justification: The described activities and expenses appear appropriate for the project and align with the goals of the funding opportunity.

recipient_justification:
This 90ZU054903 payment request is for our Mi Futuro Shelter program with a budget period of 4/1/25-3/31/26; the payment request is for program operational expenditures to run our Mi Futuro Residential Shelter program and are within our approved budgeted object class categories of Personnel, Fringe Benefits, Supplies, Contractual, Other, and Indirect. The time period of expenditures is predominantly from the second half of April 2025 and does not include any Unliquidated Obligations; prior Unliquidated Obligations from the budget period of 4/1/25-3/31/26 that have since been paid, are now included.

These operational expenditures are necessary in order to support the youth in our care and the day-to-day activities of the residential Mi Futuro Shelter program.  Expenses in this payment request are broken down into the following: the workforce staffing the program, associated workforce taxes and benefits, program supplies, contracted services (interpretation and translation of less common languages and dialects), other (building and utility expenses, information technology infrastructure, client support expenses such as food and clothing, staff training), and indirect costs. 

All current unliquidated obligations have been removed from the totals and the payment request for those expenditures will happen in subsequent periods once Morrison Child and Family Services has made payment.
agency_lead_justification: The expenses described are consistent with the purpose of the Morrison Child & Family Services program. The expenses as described are generally reasonable for this program.

recipient_justification: Funding supports the Chafee Education and Training Voucher (ETV) program, which provides up to $5,000 annually-or the cost of attendance, whichever is less-for eligible youth aging out of foster care to pursue postsecondary education. Authorized under a separate Chafee statute provision, ETV funds cover costs defined by the Higher Education Act (HEA), including tuition, fees, books, supplies, transportation, room and board, and child care. Funds may be applied to a wide range of institutions, including public, nonprofit, for-profit, and vocational schools. This payment is necessary to reduce financial barriers and support educational advancement of youth transitioning from foster care.
agency_lead_justification: The expenses described appear consistent with the purpose of the Chafee Education and Training Voucher program.

recipient_justification:
Grant award 90CI010139 is the American Indian and Alaska Native Head Start and Early Head Start funding used for center based and home based Head Start programs serving infants, toddlers and pregnant women within the tribal communities of the White Earth Reservation. Approved budget expenses for this award are staff/teacher salaries and fringe benefits, supplies such as office supplies, cleaning supplies, and curriculum supplies, groceries for serving meals to the children who attend the centers, staff travel expenses for mileage for the home based staff, basic operating costs for the centers such as electricity, fuel, phone/internet, garbage service, as well as stipends for parents who are involved with Policy Council. Indirect Cost is also an approved expense per White Earth's approved indirect cost rate agreement with the U.S. Department of Interior. 
Expenses incurred that are included in this payment reimbursement request are:
Staff Salary- $41,063.39
Fringe- $7,777.36
Staff Development- $805.64
Vehicle & Building Maintenance- $3,033.03
Instructional supplies, classroom supplies, operating supplies- $4,431.48
Groceries for serving meals at the centers- $10,834.61
Verizon, Electricity, Propane- $3,733.06

Indirect cost- $7,900.43
Total- $79,579

Expenses have already been incurred by White Earth and we are seeking reimbursement as they are all allowable grant expenses per our approved NOA. 

These are essential expenses to operate the Head Start and Early Head Start programs as they are a fully grant funded program and are essential to the education of infants and toddlers.

recipient_justification: Payments are given in accordance with the core goals of CBCAP in supporting Family Centers, also known as Family Resource Centers, that are hubs that support families by focusing on strengthening protective factors, offering robust parenting programs, and preventing child abuse and neglect. They are cost-effective and demonstrate success by incorporating parent leadership and ongoing feedback to refine and enhance services. Family Centers promote early brain development, nurture early relational health between children and caregivers, and reinforce the five protective factors—critical components of healthy child development and strategies to prevent child abuse and neglect. Research shows that Family Resource Centers lead to strong long-term outcomes and provide a significant return on investment.

recipient_justification:
To whom it may concern:
On April 21, a funding request in the amount of $166,455.00 was submitted to PMS, broken down as follows:
02CH012087-04 $ 63,000.00
02TD000136-01 $103,455.00
Today, we received a communication from HHS requesting additional information: “Additional clarification required for your recent payment request from PMS.”
The grant under subaccount 02TD00013601 was awarded for the construction of the Paraiso de Amor center. The NOA relevant remark is transcribed below.

26. REMARKS

This grant action awards Hurricane Relief funds in the amount of $1,969,449 for the 7/01/2020-06/30/2022 budget period. Funds under CAN G020700 are designated to support the restoration of Head Start and/or Early Head Start services following Hurricanes Harvey, Irma, and Maria in accordance with Office of Head Start (OHS) Program Instruction ACF-PI-HS-18-02 (the Program Instruction).
These funds are awarded following review of a funding request (application) demonstrating that the funds awarded fall within one or more of the six categories identified in the Program Instruction and are for necessary expenses directly related to the consequences of Hurricanes Harvey, Irma, and/or Maria in areas served by Fundacion para el Hogar Propio, Inc.
CONSTRUCTION: $1,969,449
Proposed improvements to the Paraíso de Amor EHS center for the following:
•	$34,046- Engineering, geotechnical, structural, land surveying, environmental, and permits.
•	$164,514- Design Services
•	$10,000- Legal Services
•	$1,545,981-Major Renovation Costs:
- The FDHP expects to serve the assigned enrollment of twenty (20) infants and toddlers in three (3) Early Head Start environments at the renovated facility. However, it will have available space for twenty-four (24) children. This would require a redistribution of the spaces in the existing structure, and partial demolition of existing walls. The structure in whole won’t be demolished. The new design solution will allow the entrance relocation of the facility from the front (street facing) to a protected area on the left side of the building (side façade). - The front façade will be covered with vegetation to soften the urban “hardness” of the immediate context. The site accommodates six parking spaces inside the center’s facilities and 15 parking spaces in its perimeter.
- The outdoor natural playground will be located on the back patio of the existing building.
26. REMARKS (Continued from previous page)

This action extends the budget and project period to January 31, 2025, for the completion of approved activities in the amount of $1,607,565 for Paraiso de Amor Center at Las Piedras, Puerto Rico.
Funds must not be expended for any other purpose(s).
The construction is nearing completion; therefore, the fund request is intended for the payment of Certification #13.
If you need any additional information, please do not hesitate to contact us.

recipient_justification: Funding is requested to provide adoption assistance in support of the adoptive placement of a child. This assistance will help offset the ongoing costs associated with the child's physical, emotional, and developmental needs, including medical care, therapy, and educational support. The adoptive family is committed to providing a safe and permanent home, and financial support is critical to ensure they can continue to meet the child's unique needs without undue hardship. Adoption assistance promotes stability and permanency, reducing the likelihood of placement disruption and aligning with state and federal goals of supporting families and reducing reliance on the foster care system. Approval of this request will help ensure the long-term success of the adoption.

recipient_justification: Maryville Academy submits this request for reimbursement under grant 90ZU060702 to cover approved program expenses incurred from 3/1/2025 to 3/31/2025, in support of our long-term group home for unaccompanied children, funded by ORR. This payment request supports the continued delivery of essential, trauma-informed services tailored to the unique and evolving needs of children in long-term residential care. Funding ensures compliance with federal guidelines while maintain quality, comprehensive support across critical areas—including bilingual case management, youth care staffing, licensed mental health services, educational programming, medical and behavioral health care, daily living essentials, meals, hygiene supplies, and facility operations. Total reimbursement amount requested is $101,956.02, which includes $10,176.78 for personnel, $35,529.33 for fringe benefits, $6,279.97 for supplies, $12,313.80 for other Program-Related Expenses, and $37,656.14 for indirect cost

recipient_justification:
These purchases were made after the approval of all expenses and are paid using unexpended funds carried over from a previous budget year.

Walnut Radio - New Sponsorship & Ad
Approved budget justification excerpt
 Promotional/Advertising –  
Local radio promotion packages with Bluffs Country 106.5/Walnut Media (requesting portion of $3,750/month 8 months). 
Essential advertising to ensure brand and EHS awareness as agency changes to Firefly, improve recruitment of EHS staff, reach eligible children and families for EHS program recruitment, and promotion of community engagement events.

Vital Signs - Welcome Sign
Approved budget justification excerpt
 – Fabrication and installation of new Firefly logo signage at the front of building space 
and illuminated interior oﬃce and wall signage to be completed by Vital Signs Unlimited, Inc. 
to identify program for families and visitors.

Creighton Power - Audio Visual
Approved budget justification excerpt
One-time purchase of audio-visual (A/V) supplies to prepare new Firefly conference rooms
 and classroom for digital optimization and virtual use for parent committee, policy council, and governing board use. A/V supply items include HDMI cables, multi-size wall-mounted monitors, and video conferencing components. No individual item will be over the $5,000 supply cap. 
Precision will be contracted to provide and install purchased A/V supplies.
Note:  In the period during which carryover approval was pending, the original estimate expired, prices rose, and the company supplying the specific service split off from the original company and was re-named.

Ultimate Block Party - Phase 1
Approved budget justification excerpt
Outdoor play space consultation services – Playful Learning Landscapes (PLLAN) will work with Firefly, property management, and a selected landscape architect (to be determined in line with agency and federal bid and procurement processes prior to beginning the construction phase of the project) to infuse intentional, accessible, and evidence-based playful learning into the to-be-built play space at Firefly’s new facility on the Charles E. Lakin Human Services Campus. No designated outdoor play space designed for the needs of EHS children currently exists on the property. The development of this play space for EHS children and families is crucial to the success of Firefly’s EHS program, will build family engagement opportunities, and provide a safe, accessible learning environment for Firefly children, caregivers, and family support specialists. The PLLAN contractual scope includes work from planning to design consultation as well as project management during the building and construction phase of the project. This is an initial and critical step in the first phase of an outdoor play space project that will begin shortly after Firefly relocation is completed. Firefly will seek additional funding support as the project enters the construction phase. property management, and a selected landscape architect (to be determined in line with agency and federal bid and procurement processes 
prior to beginning the construction phase of the project) to infuse intentional, accessible, and evidence-based playful learning into the to-be-built play space at Firefly’s new facility on the Charles E. Lakin Human Services Campus. No designated outdoor play space designed for the needs of EHS children currently exists on the property. The development of this play space for EHS children and families is crucial to the success of Firefly’s EHS program, will build family engagement opportunities, and provide a safe, accessible learning 
environment for Firefly children, caregivers, and family support specialists. The PLLAN contractual scope includes work from planning to design consultation as well as project management during the building and construction phase of the project. This is an initial and critical step in the first phase of an outdoor play space project that will begin shortly after Firefly relocation is completed. Firefly will seek 
additional funding support as the project enters the construction phase.

recipient_justification:
Time period covers April 13, 2025 to April 26, 2025. Payroll and fringe benefits encompass the total compensation provided to employees. Payroll includes salaries and wages. Fringe benefits refer to employer payroll tax obligations like Social Security, Medicare, unemployment insurance, and workers’ compensation. Also, fringe benefits refer to non-wage compensations such as employer-paid health, dental, and vision insurance, retirement plan contributions, life and disability insurance, and paid leave including vacation and sick days. Supplies refer to consumable items necessary for day-to-day operations and program delivery. This includes general office supplies and minor equipment, as well as program-specific materials such as educational tools for classroom settings.
Training and Technical Assistance (T&TA) supports the development and enhancement of staff competencies and organizational effectiveness.

recipient_justification: Continued support for the Hearing Quality Project through payments to the University of Utah for services rendered in November and December 2024. Four CIP stakeholders attended a CLE presentation aimed at enhancing courtroom practice related to evidentiary standards in child welfare cases. Salaries and benefits were provided for CIP-funded personnel (2.8 FTE). Payment of state council dues for the Utah Board of Juvenile Judges to maintain national engagement and resource access. Engagement with the National Indian Child Welfare Association (NICWA) supporting ongoing efforts to improve outcomes for Native children and families.

recipient_justification:
The NM CIP Budget includes what was formerly divided into Basic, Training, and Data Grants for a total of $355,130.00 expiring September 30, 2025 ($353,881.00 from award dated December 21, 2023, and $1,249.00 from award dated July 3, 2024). Per grant specifications, at least 30% of the total amount is to be used for collaboration and data sharing ($106,539.00). Therefore, the total budget has been broken down into two areas, Basic/Training and Collaboration and Data Sharing. 



Personnel and Benefit includes a Program Director - full time (including benefits) at 20% out of CIP and 80% out of state general funds for match; a Data Analyst – 60% time (including benefits) with 60% out of CIP, and a Program/Project Coordinator – 25% time (including benefits) with 0% out of CIP and 25% out of general funds for match.

Travel includes mileage, attendance by CCIC Members at CCIC local meetings; attendance at CIP local and national meetings, site visits to judicial districts in New Mexico, out-of-state site visits to observe best practices elsewhere. 

Contractual includes training for the judiciary, attorneys or other identified program staff, including CORE, Judicial Conclave and other trainings to facilitate quality improvement of child welfare hearings and the legal representation of parents, children, and youth via the sub recipient, Corrine Wolfe Center (CWC), previously funded by the training budget. Contractual also includes New Mexico State University's Center of Innovation for the annual Children’s Law Institute and any additional cross-training, and NMCAN youth engagement with the CCIC, the multiple CCIC Workgroups, and other regional meetings. Additionally, contractual is used for the Child and Family Service Review (CFSR) Legal and Judicial Specialist position required by the Children's Bureau for the CFSR. 

Other includes meeting space including for regional meetings, Conclave and CLI meeting room fees telecommunications, as well as postage, membership and subscription fees, advertising legal ads, and audio/visual equipment.
agency_lead_justification: The expenses described appear consistent with the purpose of the State Court Improvement Program.

recipient_justification: March 2025: a. This award is to identify and provide comprehensive evidence-based home visiting services to families who reside in at-risk communities through implementing evidence-based home visiting. The goals of the Tribal MIECHV program are to: 1) support the development of happy, healthy, and successful American Indian and Alaska Native (AIAN) children and families through a coordinated home visiting strategy that addresses critical maternal and child health, development, early learning, family support, and child abuse and neglect prevention needs; 2) implement high-quality, culturally-relevant, evidence-based home visiting programs in AIAN communities; 3) expand the evidence base around home visiting interventions with Native populations; and 4) support and strengthen cooperation and coordination and promote linkages among various early childhood programs, resulting in coordinated, comprehensive early childhood systems. b. Funds will be used to pay for workplan exp.
agency_lead_justification: The expenses described are generally reasonable and consistent with the purpose of the Tribal, Maternal, Infant, and Early Childhood Home Visiting (MIECHV) program.

recipient_justification: These funds reimburse expenditures for SRAE24 grant which is promoting sexual risk avoidance education as defined by section 1110 of the Social Security Act, for adolescents. This request covers Contractual/subaward: $95,055.52 for April 24 through April 30, 2025. These funds will support the required grant activities to teach participants how to voluntarily refrain from non-marital sexual activity, and teach the benefits associated with self-regulation, success sequencing for poverty prevention, healthy relationships, goal setting, resisting sexual coercion, dating violence, and other youth risk behaviors such as underage drinking or illicit drug use without normalizing teen sexual activity.
agency_lead_justification: The expenses described are consistent with the purpose of the Title V State SRAE program. The expenses as described are generally reasonable for this program.

recipient_justification:
This 90ZU054902 payment request is for our Mi Futuro Shelter program under the Federal Award Project Title of Residential (Shelter and/or Transitional Foster Care) Services for Unaccompanied Children-Licensed and the budget period of 4/1/24-3/31/25. The payment request is for program operational expenditures to run our Mi Futuro Residential Shelter program that are within our approved budgeted object class categories of Personnel, Fringe Benefits, Supplies, Contractual, Other, and Indirect. The time period of expenditures is predominantly from the second half of March 2025 and does not include any current Unliquidated Obligations; prior Unliquidated Obligations from the budget period of 4/1/24-3/31/25 that have since been paid, are now included. 

These operational expenditures are necessary in order to support the youth in our care and the day-to-day activities of the residential Mi Futuro Shelter program.  Expenses in this payment request are broken down into the following: the workforce staffing the program, associated workforce taxes and benefits, program supplies, contracted services (interpretation and translation of less common languages and dialects), other (building and utility expenses, information technology infrastructure, client support expenses such as food and clothing, staff training), and indirect costs. 

The object class category summaries for this payment request are as follows:
