recipient_justification:
The funds are requested to provide Training and Technical Assistance (T/TA) through regional collaboration and innovation for capacity building and quality improvement to Region V Community Services Block Grant (CSBG) Eligible Entities. Additionally, these funds are used to fuel collaboration with every CSBG cooperative forging a shared alliance to strategize (plan) and execute TTA in perfect sync with the purposes of CSBG and the goals and mission of OCS to meet and exceed the following objectives provided by OCS: . 
Objective 1: Service Delivery Models, Strategies, and Partnerships. 
Objective 2: Build and Strengthen the Knowledge, Capacity, and Ability of the Region 
to Implement Effective Programs and Activities. 
Objective 3: Regional Activities Designed to Address the Collaboration, Capacity 
Building, Quality Improvement, and TTA Needs of the Region. 
Objective 4: Relationship-building, Collaboration, and Information-Sharing Efforts 
with CSBG state-lead agencies. 
Objective 5: Regional CSBG Performance Management Framework Efforts. 
Objective 6: Storytelling and Messaging to Demonstrate the Impact of Collective 
CSBG Regional Efforts. 
Each agency in Region V has provided multiple trainings to benefit our state agencies.
In Wisconsin, We held our annual Poverty Matters Conference October 9-10, 2024. At this conference we held over 29 breakout sessions in the tracks of Public Health, Battling Food Insecurity, Housing Issues and a CCAP overview. In addition to the breakout sessions, we held two keynote presentations titled Newcap's (WI Community Action Agency) Journey to Transform Service Delivery Using the Whole Family Approach and The Art of Asking Better Questions; How the Right Questions Lead to More Efficient and Effective Outcomes.  During this time we have provided multiple virtual trainings titled: Increase Your Organizations Financial Health & Sustainability, Tackling Today’s HR and Compensation Trends with Tomorrow’s Solutions, Utilizing the WI Partnership Program’s Community Impact Grant to Improve Health and Health Equity through Housing Rehabilitation, and WISCAP Virtual Advocacy Roundtable – Local Government Advocacy. We also planned and worked to provide an OMB Uniform Guidance Training presented by Wifpli in April 2025 and an Organizational Standards Training by the National Community Action Partnership.
In Illinois during this reporting period, IACAA advanced Region V’s goal of increasing local Community Action Agency capacity to implement proven family service delivery models. We launched our new online Learning Management System (LMS) and website resource library, enrolling all Illinois agencies to support onboarding, board training, and required annual training. These tools have enabled broader access to promising practices and best-in-class resources.
We began piloting a Whole Family cohort with three participating agencies committed to shifting toward family-centered coaching models. This hands-on effort is building practical capacity for 2-Gen approaches among local agencies.
We actively contributed to Region V’s shared communication strategy through the Region V, marketing of trainings, and peer information exchanges. We also maintained ongoing collaboration with state partners to avoid duplication of efforts and promote cross-agency learning.
In Indiana they have a CSBG supported contract with the CSBG contract managers that supports a series of roundtable discussions with elements of training included. The plan is based upon the training needs expressed by CAAs within the planning documents they submit to the state.  High on the list of training topics is AI, changes in employment law and fiscal management options.
Monthly roundtable discussions on LIHEAP and HCV delivery have high levels of participation where approaches are discussed.
Weekly conversations with CAA directors on issues that sometimes include service delivery models. Obstacles to effective service delivery are frequently a discussion topic.
In Michigan, they developed a Training and Technical Assistance plan for 2024-2025. The plan was developed based on the training needs survey and with input from the state CSBG office the Bureau of Community Action and Economic Opportunity (BCAEO). MCA met with staff from BCAEO to review the plan and will continue to meet to update or review the plan.
MCA's leadership programs are in process including Leadership Development Institute and Emerging Leaders. Additional trainings offered to the member network include Introduction to ROMA and Fund Development. Planning is underway for the 2025 Summer conference which will include specific sessions on topics identified in the training needs assessment and from the state CSBG office.
In Minnesota, they Continued enhancement and increased leadership development through facilitating a leadership institute and CCAP study groups. CCAP Study Group Guide to Facilitating – MN assists other states with the learning and development of CCAP Study Leads. This is important so more CAP staff in the network can obtain their credentials and learn about the history, values and vision of Community Action. 
Improved overall well- being and knowledge  for new Executive Directors through a two- day orientation session. Region 5 New Executive Director Orientation – Act as the project coordinator. MN completes all work in this project including planning, facilitating, evaluating, etc.  This is important for the new Executive Directors of CAP’s to be able to come together to learn from one another, seek and share resources, provide informal support and build professional relationships. 
During the reporting period, the Ohio Community Action Training Organization (OCATO) supported the Region V RPIC project through its training and technical assistance work to build the capacity of the Ohio CAA network. The following describes achievements related to the overall goals of the project:
Service Delivery Models, Strategies, and Partnerships
OCATO has led an effort to create a new car repair program for low-income Ohioans to access employment, healthcare appointments and other daily needs. The program was piloted at 3 CAAs and is currently operating in the majority of the state through Ohio CAAs. OCATO plans to seek a permanent funding source for this program as it demonstrates its value.
Finally, OCATO was awarded funds under the Diaper Distribution Demonstration & Research Pilot (DDDRP) program 2023, which allows the Association to stand up a new diaper delivery system in 3 locations. To date, the project has enrolled more than distributed more than 500,000 diapers to families in need. The project will continue through April 2026 and will add an additional distribution location in 2025.

The requested funds represent allowable costs incurred to operate our programs including: facility costs, including utilities; janitorial costs; food service expenses; supplies, including classroom supplies, like construction paper, books, and manipulable toys, and office supplies; IT expenses, including software and contracted IT support; and phone and internet services.  This funding is required to maintain program operations in accordance with grant guidelines and our approved budget.
agency_lead_justification: The expenses appear to be reasonable and generally allowable for the provision of Head Start services to promote the school readiness of children from low-income families, birth to five, by fostering their cognitive, social, and emotional development through comprehensive services in early learning, health, and family well-being.

recipient_justification: The award is for the reimbursement of state expenditures related to community-based efforts to develop, operate, and coordinate initiatives, programs, and activities to prevent child abuse and neglect.  These are pass-through dollars to subawards to reimburse subrecipients for incurred personnel/payroll and direct/indirect program related expenses.  The funds in this draw centered around programs that help fathers and male caregivers throughout the state of Illinois.  These programs provide for support groups, parenting education, case navigation classes, therapeutic counseling, parent groups, and home visiting services.  Funds were also used for primary child abuse prevention activities. Program activities and expenses are in alignment with federal grant award objectives.

recipient_justification: This contract is to provide technical consultant services for maintenance, operations, and enhancements to the Hawaii Automated Network for Assistance (HANA) system that supports the employment and training and childcare services programs. HANA is the system of record for the employment and childcare services programs. HANA is an online, interactive, and integrated system used by staff to perform intake, orientation, assessment, and planning of services for families who are required to participate in the work program. In addition, HANA maintains licensing and certification information for childcare providers and eligibility and issuance information for childcare subsidy. HANA is designed to provide online client tracking, case management, payment and process automation. There are more than 300 users who access HANA functionality to support the related business processes.

recipient_justification: These expenses support Ohio’s Court Improvement Program (CIP). Travel reimbursements for staff to reflect their participation in the April 2025 CIP Steering Committee—a federal requirement—and the Regional Conference, both essential for advancing best practices and national collaboration. Subgrant payments to Cuyahoga and Clark counties fund the Multi-Disciplinary Legal Representation (MDR) program, providing crucial legal services for families in the child welfare system or at risk, an identified grant priority. Consulting fees for Robert F. Kennedy (RFK) Community Alliance support technical assistance for the Dually Involved Youth program, a key CIP strategy. The Action Research Partners payment supports the Year 3 evaluation report for the MDR Pilot Program and meets CIP required data reporting. All expenses align with CIP’s mission to improve court practices and outcomes for children and families in child welfare proceedings.
agency_lead_justification: The expenses described appear consistent with the purpose of the State Court Improvement Program.

recipient_justification: Funding is requested for foster care maintenance and administrative costs for eligible children placed in licensed foster care settings. Maintenance costs include food, clothing, shelter, daily supervision, personal incidentals, and school-related expenses necessary to ensure the well-being of children in care. Administrative costs cover case management activities, eligibility determinations, development and operation of the Comprehensive Child Welfare Information System (CCWIS), and placement services conducted by qualified agency staff. These funds are essential to maintain safety, permanency, and well-being goals for children in accordance with federal IV-E guidelines. Payment ensures continued compliance with state and federal mandates while supporting the delivery of timely and appropriate services to children and families.

Services provided can include case management, Employment and Training services (E&T), health care, daycare, nutrition programs, transportation, economic development, education, energy assistance, drug and alcohol counseling, consumer services, housing services, youth services, and outreach and referral. Funds can also be used to administer the grant.

recipient_justification: The Federal request is to pay for salaries and benefits for February March & April 2025 Budgeted under the Personnel portion of our Basic Center grant. These positions include 1 Case Manager, 1.5 youth Care Counselors, 1 Program Manager, and 1 Director of Shelter & Housing Services. In addition, the draw will pay for Client Food and program supplies under the Supplies line item of the grant budget, as well as direct client assistance and facilities expenses. The Basic Center Federal Grant is a portion of the funding for A Safe Place for Youth in Hillsboro, Oregon, which is a homeless shelter for youth in the area. The Basic Center Grant provides funds for a portion of the minors who frequent the shelter.

The costs requested include: Supplies, Rent for office where program is housed, Personnel expenses for staff providing services and coordination at Umbrella, Travel (mileage) in our rural region to and from gatherings and trainings, Contractual expenses for MOU partners who are integral to meeting our project deliverables such as those related to project coordination and direct services. Lastly, we are including indirect expenses in this request.

recipient_justification: The Texas Family Violence Program provides funding for immediate shelter and direct services for victims of dating violence, family violence and their dependents. Funds provided through the ACF Family Violence Prevention Services Act grant and expenditures under the grant directly support state personnel and operational costs to administer and oversee the grant and provide local funding to non-profit family violence organizations to provide direct services to victims. Direct services include shelter, safety planning, counseling, information and referrals, and additional supports based on victim needs. The expenses related to this request are for this purpose and have already been incurred by the grantee or state and would be considered reimbursements for those incurred expenses. All expenses are in alignment with the federally approved budget, and in accordance with all requirements with 2 CFR 200 Subpart E.

recipient_justification: The implementation of this FVPSA M funding aligns with the FVPSA definition for supportive services for adult and youth victims of family violence, domestic violence, or dating violence and their dependents, in addition to medical advocacy and other services in FVPSA at 42 U.S.C. 10408(b)(1)(A)-(H), to include the coordination of partnerships with health departments for each local program to keep families healthy and safe. These expenses align to the budget submitted upon application, which was determined with focus groups and surveys to the programs within the lens of the allowable expenses for this funding stream. These expenses are budget checked in the Center for Crime Victim Services Grants Management System. The shift in workforce expectations, because of the pandemic, has hurt the ability for these programs, with underpaid and overworked staff, to recruit the individuals needed to work 24/7 to assist Vermont families in crisis. Domestic violence emergency advocacy does not lend itself to hybrid or flex hours; this continues to exacerbate the challenges for recruitment and retention of this indispensable workforce, in an era when many job applicants seek a telecommuting option. These subgrants were delivered for the duration of the federal award, through September 30. 2025, as a word of honor, for staff retention and recruitment. For more detailed information on the lasting impact of this specialized workforce visit: Impacts of the COVID-19 Response on the Domestic Violence Workforce (https://dcadv.org/file_download/inline/411838d0-e03b-4c47-b318-fe2bff8ba191). This study aligns to the information the Center for Crime Victim Services gathered from Vermont’s DVSV programs when determining the use most judicious use of these funds. We appreciate the challenging work you do, please let us know if you need any more information.
agency_lead_justification: Expenses appear to be reasonable and generally allowable per FVPSA statute 42 U.S.C. § 10401 et seq.
org_name: VT CENTER FOR CRIME VICTIM SERVICES

award_description: HEAD START AND EARLY HEAD START
recipient_justification:
Thank you for your follow-up regarding our recent draw request submitted under the Office of Head Start grant from April 1, 2025 to May 8, 2025.
The purpose of this draw request is to support allowable and necessary programmatic expenses under our Head Start and Early Head Start grant. The request primarily covers personnel expenses for 298 staff members who are directly engaged in the execution of grant-funded activities. These positions include:
•       Classroom educators and instructional aides
•       Family support specialists and program support staff
•       Site supervisors and center directors
•       Program administrative staff supporting oversight, compliance, and reporting
All personnel costs included in this request are allocated in accordance with approved budgets and federal cost principles and reflect time dedicated exclusively to the delivery of Head Start and Early Head Start services.
In addition to payroll, the draw request also includes essential operational expenses tied to program implementation and compliance, specifically:
•       April facility payment for the North Campus facility, where multiple classrooms and family support services operate
•       Utilities and facility maintenance are critical to maintaining safe and functional learning environments
•       Educational supplies and telephone services necessary for classroom engagement and family communications
Each cost item included in this draw is reasonable, allocable, and allowable under the terms of the grant and directly contributes to the continued delivery of services to the enrolled children and families.

recipient_justification: The Carole Robertson Center divides the request of funds to cover payrolls into two parts.  The first part is an estimated calculation of 80% of the previous payroll total charged to HP-EHS, this is our estimated request.  After the current payroll payment is completed the total amount paid plus benefits and Indirect Cost is calculated; from this total the previously requested amount (estimated) is subtracted, and the remaining difference is requested, this is what we call a complement or True-up.  In this case the Center has to pay salaries for the period 04/27/2025 to 05/10/2025 on 05/16/2025, we are requesting estimated funds in advance to cover the payroll charged to HP-EHS.  The total amount charged to HP-EHS of our  previous payroll 04/13/2025 to 04/26/2025 was $69,258.67, we calculated the 80% of this amount for the payroll 04/27/2025-05/10/2025 which is $55,406.94 plus $14,243.34 of Fringe Benefits and salary taxes, plus $6.965.03 of Indirect Cost.  69,258.67 x 80% = 55,406.94 + 14,243.34 = 69,650.28 + 6,965.03 (10% for Indirect Cost)  = $76,615.31 which is the estimated amount we are requesting.

recipient_justification: The Community-Based Child Abuse Prevention (CBCAP) program provides funding to states to support communities in developing and coordinating programs and activities to ultimately mitigate the risk factors that lead to child abuse and neglect. Program activities are designed to strengthen and support families by promoting family well-being, improving parenting skills, and ensuring families have access to necessary resources. HHSC is designated by the governor as the lead agency authorized to apply for and administer the CBCAP grant program in Texas as issued by the Administration on Children, Youth and Families. HHSC, through the Family Support Services division, uses funding to provide services directly to families through the Fatherhood EFFECT program; the Service Members, Veterans, and Families program; and through Family Resource Centers. FSS contracts with local non-profits, health care providers, governments, schools, and other community-based providers to deliver program services
agency_lead_justification: The expenses described appear consistent with the purpose of the Community-Based Child Abuse Prevention program.

recipient_justification: Award 09CH01184604 supports funding to Acelero Learning Clark County Head Start programs.  In Head Start programs, we provide high quality early childhood education services for low income children ages three-to-five. The requested funds represent allowable costs incurred to operate our programs including: rent and facility costs; insurance; food service expenses, and supplies, including classroom supplies, like construction paper, books, and manipulable toys. recipient_justification:
Award Number: 90CU0124- 03

Federal award Title: Young Child Parent Project-Two

Project Period: 09/30/2024 to 09/29/2025

Summary of approved expenses/activities: The Health Federation of Philadelphia Young Child and Parent Project-Two (YCPP2) provides evidence-based interventions, cross-systems collaboration, and training in two counties of Pennsylvania (Philadelphia and Bucks) with severe substance use and child welfare challenges.

The clinical intervention for YCPP2 combines Mothering from the Inside Out and Child Parent Psychotherapy (MIO-CPP). These services are offered to pregnant or parenting people who are enrolled in residential substance use disorder treatment programs in Philadelphia and Bucks counties and whose children, ages 0-5, are at risk of or receiving child welfare services (including prevention or in-home services).

The objectives include increasing parental child attachment and reflective functioning; improving care coordination, recovery, and relapse prevention for families; and improving community and workforce capacity to serve families with young children through cross-system training and collaborative meetings.

PolicyLab at Children’s Hospital of Philadelphia conducts the local evaluation. The project is also participating in the RPG cross-site evaluation studies of family and child outcomes, program implementation, and collaboration among RPG recipients and partners.

The expenses used to provide these program services are as follows:

Direct Cost

Personnel: $46,819.80

Salaries for Project Director; Clinical Director; Child Parent Therapists (2); Grant Manager

Fringe benefits: $ 14,982.34

Calculated at 32% to include social security (7.65%); unemployment (.65%); workers compensation (.75%), health/dental/life insurance (17%); retirement (5%); other fringe (0.45%) -short-term & long-term disability.

Total Personnel and Fringe Benefits: $ 61,802.14   

Supplies
Program Materials: $663.00

Cost of program materials/supplies for MIO-CPP/child-development/parent child interactions/activities and incentives.

OTHER

Property Rent and Utilities:  $400.00

Cost of office space and utilities for staff

Staff Transportation Local: $2,142.52

Cost for mileage calculated at .70/mile and parking for staff to attend project related meetings and home visits in Philadelphia and Bucks counties.

Communications: $422.60

Expenses for 3 cellular phones for the staff while in the field; RingCentral phone system;  Zoom (HIPAA compliant) virtual platform for meetings with participants and providers; Vitru for encrypted emails (HIPAA Compliant) to coordinate care with other providers; Data for 6 laptops to be used at our partners’ sites to facilitate evaluation activities.

Total Direct Cost: $65,430.50

Total Indirect Cost: $8,466.89

Calculated at 13.7% of personnel and fringe benefits

Total program drawdown request: $73,897.39
agency_lead_justification: This request appears to align with the grant program and approved grant application.

recipient_justification:
AFN ICWA Best Practice Initiative Payment Request Justification
Supporting transparency and accountability

Payment Request amount
71,548.11
Payment Details
Program name: Alaska Federation of Natives, Inc.
Period covered: January, February and March 2025
I. Introduction
The long-term outcome is to develop sustainable State-Tribal systems that embrace and support responsive policies, programs, and practices that strengthen families and nurture safety, well-being, and permanency while fostering long-term savings for the State of Alaska and the Federal Government. The demonstration grant seeks to develop a sustainable alternative response systemic practice model that runs parallel to the state system, prevents low—and moderate-risk AN/AI children from coming into state custody, and improves outcomes for AN/AI children and families. Alaska Native children are 6.1% of Alaska’s general population; yet they comprise 29.2% of substantiated protective service reports and 68% of the children in out-of-home care in 2023

II. Cost Categories 
•  A. Personnel: 
Nicole Borromeo, VP of AFN, Project Director, Annual Salary $280,665.00.  During January-March, 18% of her hours went to the ICWA grant as the Project Director, which equals 2.2% of her salary, $6,138.98. Fringe was $1,263.18, which is employer tax and health insurance. NB’s last day with AFN was 1.20.25
This Position provides oversight of program staff, monitors progress towards completion of grant goals and objectives, monitored the program budget, facilitated planning and communications with program partners, coordinated research and Initiative activities, and completed timely reporting requirements.		
						
Rodreshia Dunbar, ICWA Grant Project Manager, has an annual salary of $120,000.00, and 100% of her time is focused on this ICWA grant, which is $18,461.52. Fringe was $1,638.90.
This position works directly with the Project Director and is responsible for the day-to-day supervision of the program. Program staff, as well as providing coordination of the planning phase, participating in partnership meetings, coordinating with evaluators and other contractors, as well as ACF and TA providers, and establishing community referral pathways.







 
•  B. Travel: Semi-Annual In-Person Meeting
Francine Eddy Jones, Strategic Planner and consultant, traveled from Juneau to Anchorage from 2/26/25 to 03/01/25. 
This meeting was mandatory with AFN leadership, Casey Family Program, and Tribal Partners. Total cost for travel (airfare/hotel) was $1,118.30.
Francine came to the meeting to assist in identifying grant needs (activities, goals, outcomes), developing a communication plan, updating the grant implementation plan, researching other models, and preparing IRB applications.

•  C. Supplies: 
a. Meeting Supplies 
Sweet Caribou, a restaurant that supplied food to meeting participants, supported an in-person meeting in Anchorage. During the meeting, AFN and partners re-established a new teaming structure and implementation plan after losing the two key grant management team leaders. The team has focused on identifying needs, developing a communication plan, updating the grant implementation plan, researching other models, preparing IRB applications, developing a white paper, and planning for data collection and analysis. The supply expense for the meeting was $276.10.

b. Stipends for Elders/Community Subject Matter Expert 
Amber Grace Etageak, a community subject matter expert, received $50.00 to participate in an initiative meeting. The meeting laid down the framework for data collection that will be utilized to inform the development of a model and its training curriculum, a necessary goal for the sustainability of grant deliverables.

•  D. Consultants (contracts):
	
Rodreshia Dunbar was a full-time Tribal Welfare consultant; she now works for AFN full-time to carry out the project manager position, ½ month of contract work for January, before becoming a full-time employee as the new Project Director. The cost for ½ of the January contract was $2,323.00.
Implementation support and managing activities around the implementation plan.
Around the areas of Implementation, it provides coordination, facilitation, and documentation of Planning Phase meetings and activities, Advisory Committee and Child Welfare System partner meetings; development of governance, policy, and process updates and documentation; and support in creating final documentation of planning activities for submission to the federal funding agencies for consideration.

Francine Eddy Jones is a full-time Tribal Welfare consultant. Contracted monthly cost $2,592.00.  
Strategic planning and assistance with implementation.  Strategic planning and implementation support, provides coordination, facilitation, and documentation of Planning Phase meetings and activities, Advisory Committee and Child Welfare System partner meetings; development of governance, policy, and process updates and documentation, and support creating final documentation of planning activities for submission to the federal funding agencies for consideration.  


•  E. Sub-Contracts: 
Washington State University: This subcontract pays for the development of an evaluation plan, revision of the program logic model and theory of change, participation in the assessment process to establish baselines and propose performance measurements, and preparation for the collection and analysis of data and identification of areas of improvement.  Supports the long-term goal of establishing an ICWA best practices model.  This expense is for December, January, and February, $2,697.64 monthly.  

Haa Yaitxu:  AFN established a contract for curriculum development. The grant is for a community-based program called Kin Support Program to develop an innovative cost-saving prevention curriculum as part of the intervention prevention aspect of the ICWA Best Practice model. The program aims to prevent children at high risk of coming into care by providing support and services to relatives (kin). This is a bi-annual cost; $18,918.57 is for this period. The contract is an total annual cost of 35,000.00

•  F. Other Direct Costs: 
Accounting AFN hires a contract accountant to ensure all accounting complies with local, state and Federal rules.  The accounting expense is work directly associated with this grant.  Accounts payable, monthly reconciliations, confirming expenses, drawdowns, budget, and what is left to spend. This ensures the grant and AFN are in compliance. The cost for January was $1,578.27,

•  G. Indirect Costs: 
AFN uses the 10% federal indirect rate.  AFN applies the 10% indirect rate to all drawdowns. 
Grant Exp paid in Jan. $9,725.15/ Add 10% Indirect $972.51/ Total Draw Down, $10,697.67
Grant Exp paid in Feb. $20,805.13/ Add 10% Indirect $2,080.51/ Total Draw Down, $22,885.64
Grant Exp paid in March $34,513.46/ Add 10% Indirect $3,451.34/ Total Draw Down, $37,964.80

recipient_justification:
The TANF program was developed to provide support to low income families with cash assistance and services that meet one of the four purposes of TANF, which include:
1.	Provide assistance to needy families so that children can be cared for in their own homes or in the homes of relatives
2.	End the dependence of needy parents on government benefits by promoting job preparation, work, and marriage
3.	Prevent and reduce the incidence of out-of-wedlock pregnancies
4.	Encourage the formation and maintenance of two-parent families
The funds being requested are to reimburse funds spent for cash assistance to families who are eligible for Nebraska’s Aid to Dependent Children cash assistance program, the Employment First program, Nebraska’s welfare to work program and all community based programs that are currently contracted to provide services that meet one of the other purposes of TANF. These programs include child care costs, child welfare programs, home visiting, The Healthy Fatherhood Initiative, Child Advocacy Centers and others that have been approved by ACF through Nebraska’s state plan. In addition to the programs and services, funds will also be utilized for the administration of the program and system updates to ensure that the programs are able to continue. 
These programs are necessary to continue working with families to increase self-sufficiency through employment and training opportunities to move participants to employment opportunities, address concerns that are preventing their family from a two parent family, and focusing on keeping families together. Each program offered in Nebraska is focused on working with families to provide education and opportunities that will assist them in understanding the importance of employment, family and reducing generational poverty for their family.
agency_lead_justification: The clarification described expenses that are consistent with those that are reasonable for accomplishing the statutory purposes of TANF.
